**Prohibition of Sales to EEA Retail Investors**

The Notes are not intended to be offered, sold or otherwise made available to and should not be offered,
sold or otherwise made available to any retail investor in a member state of the EEA. For the purposes
of this paragraph, a retail investor means a person who is one (or more) of: (a) a retail client as defined
in point (11) of Article 4(1) of Directive 2014/65 (as amended, “MiFID II”); (b) a customer within the
meaning of Directive (EU) 2016/97 (the “Insurance Distribution Directive”), where that customer
would not qualify as a “professional client” as defined in point (10) of Article 4(1) of MiFID II; or (c)
not a “qualified investor” as defined in Regulation (EU) 2017/1129 (as amended, the “Prospectus
**Regulation”).**

Consequently no key information document required by Regulation (EU) No 1286/2014 (as amended,
the “PRIIPs Regulation”) for offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making them available to retail
investors in the EEA has been prepared and therefore offering or selling the Notes or otherwise making
them available to any retail investor in the EEA may be unlawful under the PRIIPs Regulation.

This Offering Memorandum has been prepared on the basis that any offer of Notes in any member state
of the EEA will be made pursuant to an exemption under the Prospectus Regulation from the
requirement to publish a prospectus for offers of Notes. This Offering Memorandum is not a prospectus
for the purposes of the Prospectus Regulation.

**market: Solely for the purposes of each manufacturer’s product approval process, the target market**
assessment in the EEA in respect of the Notes described in the Offering Memorandum has led to the
conclusion that: (i) the target market for the Notes is professional clients and eligible counterparties,

from the use of legacy systems for the calculation of revenue, which had only been used by the Swiss
operating segment and had been in place since before the Fitness World Acquisition. The error resulted

corresponding overstatement of prepayments and trade receivables (presented in the balance sheet
within trade and other receivables) and understatement of contract liabilities – membership income
(presented in the balance sheet under trade and other payables). The error also resulted in an
overstatement of VAT payable (presented in the balance sheet under trade and other payables) in line
with the overstatement of revenue.

As a result, certain amounts in the Group’s consolidated statement of comprehensive income for the
year ended December 31, 2021 and consolidated statement of financial position for the years ended
December 31, 2021 and December 31, 2020 presented in this Offering Memorandum have been derived
from the unaudited comparative amounts presented in the 2022 Financial Statements. For more
information see Note 30 of the 2022 Financial Statements and Note 15 of the Unaudited Condensed
Consolidated Interim Financial Statements.

Furthermore, in our 2021 Financial Statements, we restated certain unaudited comparative amounts in
the consolidated cash flow statement to reflect the correction of a misstatement of the drawdown and
repayment amounts of the Existing Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility in the Group’s
2020 Financial Statements. The misstatement resulted in a £50,000,000 overstatement of repayment of
revolving credit facility in the year ended December 31, 2020 and a corresponding £50,000,000
overstatement of the drawdown on revolving credit facility for the same period. The error was confined
to these two line items, and the restatement did not impact the net drawdown. For more information see

**Non-IFRS Measures**

This Offering Memorandum contains certain non-IFRS measures and ratios, including Adjusted
EBITDA, Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA, Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA and certain other measures (the
“Non-IFRS Measures”) that are not required by, or presented in accordance with, IFRS or the
accounting standards of any other jurisdiction. We define the following Non-IFRS Measures as follows:

- “Adjusted EBITDA” as the profit or loss for a certain period before income tax expense, net
finance cost, depreciation and impairment of property, plant and equipment and right of use assets,
amortization and impairment of intangible fixed assets, profit/loss on disposal of property, plant
and equipment, profit/loss on lease modifications, exceptional administrative expenses, and other
adjustments, after adding back Pre-Opening Costs and share based payment charges and
subtracting the Cash Rent Adjustment.

- “Adjusted EBITDA margin” as Adjusted EBITDA for that period divided by revenue for that
period.

- “As adjusted Net Debt” represents total senior secured indebtedness of the Group less cash and
cash equivalents, after giving _pro forma_ effect to the Transactions and the application of the
proceeds therefrom as if the Transactions had occurred on December 31, 2022.

- “As adjusted Net Interest Expense” represents the net of interest payable/receivable for the 12
months ended December 31, 2022 after giving _pro forma_ effect to the Transactions and the
application of the proceeds therefrom as if the Transactions occurred on January 1, 2022.

- “Average Continuous Membership Tenure” as the average monthly tenure of all active and
paying members, including members who have frozen their membership, as of a given point in
time. This includes previous memberships where the gap in membership was 30 days or less, but
excludes the period(s) of non-membership.

- “Average Gym ROCE” as Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA for the relevant portfolio of gyms for that
period divided by the Initial Capital Investment attributable to that portfolio of gyms.

- “Average Initial Capital Investment for Mature Gyms” as the Initial Capital Investment for all
Mature Gyms for a certain period divided by the number of Mature Gyms in that period.

- “Average Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA” as Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA for a certain
period divided by the number of Mature Gyms in that period.

- “Average Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA Margin” as Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA for a
certain period divided by the revenue attributable to Mature Gyms for that period.

iii


-----

- “Average Mature Gym ROCE” as Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA for a certain portfolio of
gyms for a certain period divided by the Initial Capital Investment attributable to that portfolio of
gyms.

- “Average Revenue per Member per Month” as revenue for that period divided by the number
of months in that period and further divided by the average number of members during that period.
The average number of members during that period is calculated as the average of the number of
members at corporate gyms as of the beginning of the first month and the end of every month in
that period.

- “Cash Rent Adjustment” as the deduction of the cash rent payable during the period which
otherwise was not reflected in EBITDA (as reported on a post-IFRS 16 basis). From 2021 onwards,
the Cash Rent Adjustment excludes the cash impact of COVID-19 rent deferments. Therefore,
Adjusted EBITDA more closely reflects the underlying trading results of the Group for the period.

- “EBITDA” as the profit or loss for a certain period before income tax expense, net finance cost,
depreciation and impairment of property, plant and equipment and right of use assets, amortization
and impairment of intangible fixed assets, profit/loss on disposal of property, plant and equipment,
profit/loss on lease modifications and exceptional administrative expenses.

- “Expansionary Capital Expenditure” as the Initial Capital Investment and the capital costs of
expanding corporate-owned gyms incurred in that period, and the capital costs of investments in
technology in that period.

- “Gym cohorts” as groups of clubs that opened during a specified period.

- “Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA” as Adjusted EBITDA for that period, excluding Head Office
Costs.

- “Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA margin” as Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA divided by revenue for
that period.

- “Head Office Costs” as all non-gym specific costs, other than depreciation and amortization,
related to the operation of head office functions in a given period.

- “Initial Capital Investment” refers to the capital cost of bringing a new gym into operation or
extending a gym, including expenditures on site fit out, fixtures, fittings and equipment and
excluding the cost of any right of use property assets, ongoing maintenance and refurbishment
capex.

- “Maintenance and Refurbishment Capital Expenditures” as the total capital expenditure
incurred in a period less Expansionary Capital Expenditure incurred in that period.

- “Mature Gym Adjusted EBITDA” as profit for a certain period before income tax expense, net
finance cost, depreciation and impairment of property, plant and equipment and right of use assets,
amortization and impairment of intangible fixed assets, profit/loss on disposal of property, plant
and equipment, profit/loss on lease modifications and exceptional administrative expenses for
mature sites, after adding back the Cash Rent Adjustment and Pre-Opening Costs for mature sites
and after adding back Head Office Costs.

- “Mature Gym EBITDA” as profit for a certain period before income tax expense, net finance
cost, depreciation and impairment of property, plant and equipment and right of use assets,
amortization and impairment of intangible fixed assets, profit/loss on disposal of property, plant
and equipment, profit/loss on lease modifications, exceptional administrative expenses and Head
Office Costs for Mature Gyms. Mature Gym EBITDA does not include the Cash Rent Adjustment

i


-----

or adjustments for Pre-Opening Costs or other extraordinary items that were added back to
Adjusted EBITDA and Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA.

- “Mature Gyms” as corporate-owned gyms that have been open for two full financial years or
more as at the reporting date.

- “New Gyms” as corporate-owned gyms that have been open for less than two full financial years
as at the reporting date.

- “Operating Cash Flow” as Adjusted EBITDA plus Working Capital Cash Flow and less
Maintenance and Refurbishment Capital Expenditure cash flows for that period.

- “Operating Cash Flow Conversion” as the Operating Cash Flow for that period divided by
Adjusted EBITDA for that period.

- “Pre-Opening Costs” as the total of all gym site operating costs incurred during the pre-opening
periods of gyms in that period. Pre-Opening Costs primarily consist of staff and marketing
expenses.

- “ROCE” is the return on capital employed, calculated as the Initial Capital Investment attributable
to that portfolio of gyms divided by Adjusted EBITDA for the relevant portfolio of gyms for that
period.

- “Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA” as the Adjusted EBITDA including any Run-Rate Adjustment.

- “Run-Rate Adjustment” as the adjustment made to both corporate-owned and franchise gyms
which are less than three years old at the end of the reporting period. These adjustments replace
the Adjusted EBITDA earned by these sites in the last twelve month period with the projected
Adjusted EBITDA for their third year of operation.

- “Senior secured net debt” is the total senior secured indebtedness of the Group (excluding finance
lease liabilities as reported under IAS17), less cash & cash equivalents.

- “Total Capital Expenditure cash flow” as Maintenance and Refurbishment Capital Expenditure
cash flow and Expansionary Capital Expenditure cash flow incurred in the period.

- “Total debt (excluding IFRS 16 lease liabilities)” as total senior secured debt plus non-property
lease liabilities.

- “Working Capital Cash Flow” as cash movements in working capital.

We present a reconciliation of the Non-IFRS Measures to the most directly comparable measure
calculated and presented in accordance with IFRS and discuss its limitations. For a reconciliation of
these Non-IFRS Measures and such discussions, refer to “Summary Consolidated Financial and Other
_Information—Other financial, operational and pro forma data.”_

We believe that the presentation of the Non-IFRS Measures enhances an investor’s understanding of
our operating performance and our ability to service our debt. In addition, we believe that EBITDA is
a measure commonly used by investors. Our Non-IFRS Measures may not be comparable with similarly
titled measures used by other companies. Our EBITDA and related leverage and coverage ratios are not
measurements of financial performance under IFRS and should not be considered as alternatives to
other indicators of our operating performance, cash flows or any other measure of performance derived
in accordance with IFRS. Our Non-IFRS Measures have important limitations as analytical tools, and
you should not consider them in isolation or as substitutes for analysis of our results of operations as

**Overview**

We are the second largest gym and fitness operator in Europe by number of gyms, with over 550 sites
and approximately 1.9 million members across our estate. We provide high quality, low cost, flexible
physical fitness facilities and have market leading positions in each of our three key markets: the UK,
Denmark and Switzerland.

Our operating model provides a powerful customer proposition that is differentiated from traditional
gym operators and appeals to a broad range of consumers. The key elements of our model proposition
include affordable membership fees, flexible contracts, a large footprint in each of our key markets and
24/7 access (in most locations) to high-quality gyms. This proposition is underpinned by the
differentiated, capital-efficient and technology-enabled gym operating model, which enables us to
support high levels of membership, operate on low costs and generate strong unit economics, cash flow
conversion and ROCE, and provides us with a strong platform for expansion.

Our strategic mission is to be a leading provider of affordable and flexible fitness memberships to
high-quality fitness facilities in current and new markets. Our customer value proposition, differentiated
business model and well-managed growth strategy has allowed us to grow rapidly in multiple
geographies through new site roll-outs, acquisitions and membership expansion. We are the largest
operator of gyms in the UK both by number of gyms and members. Following our acquisition of the
Fitness World Group in 2020, we also became the leading operator in Denmark by number of gyms and
members and the leading value gym operator in Switzerland by number of gyms and members. In 2021,
we launched a franchise model with the first franchised sites opening in the Middle East, which has
allowed us to bring our affordable, accessible gym proposition to a number of exciting new markets
and provides a platform for expanding our franchised offering to other territories in the future. In 2022,
we also opened our first three corporate-owned gyms in the U.S. with over 11,000 members as of
June 30, 2023.

For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we generated revenue of £515.3 million and a Run-Rate
Adjusted EBITDA of £128.4 million, an increase of 14% and 19%, respectively, from the twelve
months ended June 30, 2022.

**Key Strengths**

We believe that our key strengths are as follows:

**_Attractive and resilient fitness market driven by the winning value segment gym model_**

The European health and fitness club market had total revenues of €28 billion as of December 2022,
almost reaching the pre-COVID-19 revenues of €28.2 billion as of December 2019 (Source:
_Deloitte/EuropeActive Report), and similarly, fitness club membership volumes are recovering towards,_
and in some markets beyond, pre-COVID-19 levels. Memberships are showing consistent growth across
most European geographies, driven by structural trends towards greater consumer health awareness and
high importance, government support and promotion of fitness, as well as continued increase in gym
capacity. Over the four years from February 2015 to February 2019, gym membership in Europe was

1


-----

estimated to have increased from 54 million to 65 million, which reflects an estimated CAGR of 4.8%
(Source: OC&C Report). In 2022, European memberships increased by approximately 7 million
members, or 12% from 56 million in 2021 to 63 million (Source: Deloitte/EuropeActive Report).

The value gym segment, in which we operate, has continued its long-term growth in both volume and
market share terms, as operators have expanded the market by providing affordable fitness options to
an underserved population. In all our key geographic markets, the value gym segment has continued to
gain share. In Europe, between 2015 and 2022, the share of net gym membership additions by 15 out
of the top 20 value operators was 91%. In all our core markets of the UK, Denmark and Switzerland
the value gym segment has also grown its share of memberships. For example, in the UK (the largest
market in Europe by revenue), between February 2015 and February 2023, value operators accounted
for 82% of net new member additions, meaning value share increased from 20% in 2016 to 28% in
2022, and again to 30% in 2023 (Source: Deloitte/EuropeActive Report, OC&C Report).

We believe the value fitness model will have greater overall success, compared to traditional fitness
models, due to its scalability and because it is economically superior to traditional gym center operating
models. The model generates significantly higher EBITDA due to lower costs (approximately £0.4
million EBITDA for a value gym as compared to approximately £0.3 million EBITDA for a mid-market
gym), lower capital expenditure to fit out each unit (£1.0 to £1.5 million for a value gym as compared
to £1.5 to £2.0 million for a mid-market gym). This delivers higher and more sustainable ROCE
(approximately 35% for a value gym as compared to approximately 18% for a mid-market gym)
(Source: Company information). For more information, see “—Operating model combines strong
_revenue management and low labor cost.”_

The gym market has demonstrated resilience during periods of both economic uncertainty and the
COVID-19 pandemic. The COVID-19 pandemic caused unprecedented disruption to the fitness
industry, causing gyms to close across all markets in Europe and inevitably membership numbers
declined significantly during these periods of disclosure. In spite of this, the market has recovered very
strongly and is now back to pre-pandemic levels. See “Industry Overview—Overview of the gym-based
_fitness market.” Many of the larger operators have emerged stronger following the pandemic, as gym_
operators required strong liquidity positions to be able to withstand the periods of extended closure
during local and nationwide lockdowns. Some weaker operators in both the value and mid-market gym
segments exited their respective markets, thereby increasing available space for expansion and creating
underserved demand. In addition, we believe that even if a weakened competitor did not exit the market,
it will, in general, struggle to maintain product quality because it will lack the resources to reinvest and
will struggle to raise new capital in the now more challenging market for financing.

The gym market has also traded strongly through previous economic downturns. This is well
demonstrated by data through the global financial crisis in 2008 and 2009, evidenced by an estimated
2.1% CAGR in total gym spend in the UK health and fitness club market between 2006 and 2012.
During this time period total gym spend did not fall during any individual year. From 2008 to 2012,
value gyms grew significantly, with membership increasing by an estimated CAGR of 121% (Source:
_OC&C Report)._

As the market figures show, gyms have continued to perform strongly through the recent economic
downturn. For example, in the UK memberships are estimated to have increased from 9.5 million in
February 2022 to 10 million in February 2023, representing an increase of over 5%. Consumer research
shows that consumers prioritize their gym memberships ahead of other areas of discretionary spend
such as eating out, holidays and clothing (Source: OC&C Report).

Against this backdrop, the value sector in the UK has performed particularly well, growing from
approximately 2.7 million memberships to 3.0 million memberships, from February 2022 to
February 2023, which is an increase of 10%. During this period, the value sector has benefitted from
members of premium, mid-market, and public sector gyms trading down, with a net inflow of 219,000
members between 2022 and 2023 alone (Source: OC&C Report).

Furthermore, we believe that the difficult macroeconomic environment seen in 2022 and the first half
of 2023 has provided further challenges for many businesses with pressure from energy costs, general
inflation, interest rates and consumers acting more cautiously. Because strong, well-capitalized players,
such as the Group, will be able to maintain product quality, our relative competitive position will, we
believe, improve over time. This is further evidenced by our cost of living indicators (such as website
traffic, web conversion rate, existing member upgrades, joiner ARPM (as defined below), member

generally increased or remained consistent year over year in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023.
Additionally, in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, our UK bad debt collection rate was consistent
with the rate for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. Despite the impact of COVID-19, concomitant
governmental lockdowns and a challenging macroeconomic environment, we have managed the
business well, having retained our leading market positions, optimized our cost structure, opened 98
sites between January 2020 and June 30, 2023 and continued to increase total member numbers to
1,855,000 as of June 30, 2023. For more on our resilience, see “—Excellent performance management

**_Excellent core product offering delivered across a broad range of site sizes_**

Our core product offering includes the following features:

- _High-quality facilities and inclusive philosophy—we aim to “offer a boutique fitness experience at_
a value gym price.” Our gyms are equipped with a large number of pieces of high-specification
gym equipment, including a broad selection of cardio machines, fixed resistance machines, free
weights and functional and other exercise equipment, such as TRX bands and kettlebells. Our gyms
are clean, well-maintained and are fitted out with high-quality changing rooms and shower
facilities. We offer a welcoming environment and support all members in the pursuit of their fitness
goals, regardless of their current abilities. This is demonstrated, for example, by our “everybody
welcome” philosophy;

- _Superior convenience and proximity to customers as a result of well-developed club network—we_
have the largest and most extensive gym network in the UK and Denmark, with over 50% more
sites in the UK than our closest competitor. This allows us to capitalize on potential members’
desire for proximity. We believe this to be a competitive advantage, given that research indicates
that proximity is among the top two most important factors for members when choosing a gym. In
Denmark we enjoy an even larger market share position and both scale and network advantage
than in the UK when compared to other operators;

- _Group exercise classes—we have dedicated group exercise studios, including purpose-built_
stationary cycling studios in many locations. Most of our gyms offer a wide variety of over 50
classes per week, taught by fitness professionals. Other operators in the value market do not
typically offer such an extensive range of group exercise classes;

- _Membership and access options—we offer flexibility through our range of enrollment offers,_
extended opening hours, premium or off-peak membership options and online membership
management; and

- _Highly effective utilization of space—unlike many mid-market and premium operators, we do not_
install pools, spas, saunas, steam room, extensive cafes or other high-end amenities in our gyms.
These amenities are generally expensive to construct, operate and maintain and take up a
significant amount of leased space. We believe that these amenities are generally less utilized by
members and that by eliminating them we are able to install more pieces of high utilization fitness
equipment, such as treadmills, free weights and stationary bikes. As a result, our gyms can support
high levels of membership while operating on low operating and initial capital investment costs.

Our core product offering is hard to replicate at scale, due to our strong presence and member loyalty
in our key markets, and underpins our market leading positions as the number one value gym operator
in the UK, Denmark and Switzerland and number two gym operator in Europe.

**_Great consumer value proposition_**

We have a compelling consumer value proposition. Key elements of this proposition include:

- _Flexible membership—members can sign up with flexible contracts. Accordingly, members have_
the freedom and the flexibility to leave at their convenience without incurring cancellation fees
and have the ability to freeze their memberships for months at a time;

- _Easy to join and online membership management—our online website and app platforms allow_
members to join in just two minutes, manage their memberships, freeze or cancel their
membership, book classes, locate gym facilities, track fitness data and engage in fitness challenges.
This ability to self-serve is convenient for members and lowers costs for the business;

- _Digital integration—we blend high-tech with high performance, including digital studios,_
interactive screens, a coherent online offer and content for workouts and exercise at home when
not in the gym, all of which are available via the PureGym app;

- _Affordable pricing—our flexible and low-cost membership structure provides excellent value for_
money for our members, with student discounts, day passes and off-peak membership options
available in many locations. These options further minimize costs for our members, often enabling
access to affordable fitness where there previously was none. Our variable pricing model, tailored
to the local market, is crucial to maximizing performance and allows us to tailor the offer to each
individual location;

- _Multi-gym access—members can buy an option to access any of our gyms in each country, many_
of which are open 24/7; and

- _Quality equipment and classes—we offer quality gyms, with members able to access_
approximately 50 face-to-face classes per week in many gyms, combined with nutrition, equipment
and personal training options.

Members receive all the above for a price significantly lower than in typical mid-market and premium
gyms. Our average monthly revenue per member was £24.55 as at June 30, 2023 and £24.61 for the six
months ended June 30, 2023, with mid-market and premium gyms typically charging significantly
more.

**_Operating model combines strong revenue management and low labor cost_**

We believe that the value fitness model is economically superior to traditional gym and fitness center
operating models through a combination of low fit-out capex, low equipment and maintenance spending
and high membership density. We believe that the resulting average return on invested capital, per site,
in value gyms is approximately double compared to a typical mid-market operators. As a result, those
operators who successfully deploy the value business model (such as the Group and our international
peers, Basic-Fit, SmartFit and Planet Fitness), benefit from attractive unit margins, rapid paybacks on
initial investment and high ROCE. Therefore, they are able to quickly redeploy capital to support further
network growth, further enhancing scale and associated economies. Our operating model benefits from
the following features:

- _Low personnel costs—we are able to operate our gyms with low levels of employed personnel_
primarily through the use of technology. For example, we offer an online and app-based enrollment
process, which eliminates the need for a dedicated in-gym sales forces, which are commonly used
by mid-market and premium operators. Members also use fully-automated PIN-controlled entry
portals, QR readers for apps, or member cards to facilitate secure access to our gyms, which largely

eliminates the need for staff covering reception desks to control entry. We believe we can further
increase personnel cost efficiency, and thereby improve margins, by applying some best practices
from our operating model to our more recently acquired gyms in continental Europe through
measures such as unmanned hours covered by video surveillance with tailored alert systems;

- _Pricing sophistication—we have built sophisticated pricing capability, which gives us the ability_
to employ variable pricing in all gyms in order to tailor our price point to the specific local market.
This allows us to adapt to local markets by managing member enrollment, refine promotional
investment and thus optimize revenues;

- _Purchasing scale—we are one of only a small number of large, global, value fitness businesses._
This provides us with purchasing scale across our key geographies and results in lower costs. We
believe we are the largest purchaser of gym equipment in our key geographies from leading
suppliers including Matrix and Precor, thereby reducing the costs of constructing and operating
our gyms (such procurement costs for equipment costs can, we believe, be up to 30% to 40% lower
for large players and fit out costs can be up to 10% to 20% lower);

- _Ability to invest—our scale and resources allow us to rapidly develop new sites and invest in other_
areas of our business, such as technology, which enable us to operate more efficiently and deliver
a better customer experience. Our reinvestment and refurbishment capability further differentiates
us from smaller cash-constrained competitors;

- _Brand—we have an international brand that benefits from higher levels of brand awareness than_
other value gym operator in our key markets. The scale and both nationwide and international
footprints allow us to effectively pursue marketing campaigns such as social media and TV
advertisements. We invest digitally, nationally and locally to build brand awareness and
consideration. Our brand is also supplemented by our PureGym app, with many users and a wide
reaching, highly engaged social media following. For example, as at June 30, 2023, in the UK, the
brand benefits from a combined social media following of over 1.5 million users across all major
channels and both national and local gym accounts. In Denmark, despite the fact that the PureGym
brand was only launched in 2023, we have achieved online traffic shares of 50%-60% versus our
close competition (Source: _Company information); and_

- _Leading marketing expertise driving strong brand awareness—we have an increasingly_
sophisticated, multi-channel digital-led marketing strategy, which is not overly reliant on any
single channel. We employ a range of marketing techniques through various media channels in
order to promote a contemporary and differentiated brand, which would be difficult for new
entrants to replicate given our resources and prior marketing experience.

Our highly predictable new site performance and strong unit economics drive sustainable margins,
excellent cohort performance and cash flow generation. We believe that our performance metrics
demonstrate that we have developed a leading operating model in the value gym arena, with a revenue

**Strategy**

Our strategy is to further expand our position as a market-leading value gym operator by providing
affordable, flexible and value-for-money memberships in high-quality gyms to anyone who wants to

9


-----

increase their level of fitness, while simultaneously delivering profitable growth. The key elements of
our strategy include:

**_Exploit structural growth opportunity in value gym sector_**

We plan to take advantage of both the opportunity to drive significantly increased penetration of gym
usage and the market shift from mid-market and premium gyms to value gyms. For more on how value
gyms are disrupting the market and taking market share, see “—Key Strengths—Attractive and resilient
_fitness market driven by the winning value segment gym model.” We plan to leverage our experience to_
continue the organic roll-out of new gyms with strong ROCE. Future growth in the value segment will
be driven by the development of new value gyms, continued market share gains from mid-market and
premium operators, as well as public gyms operated by local authorities, and overall growth in gym
participation rates due in part to the increasing awareness and availability of value gyms in each of our
markets. The significant opportunity for further growth in the value gym market is evidenced by:

- the significant success of the value gym concept to date and its broad consumer appeal;

- the current overall penetration rates of gym membership in existing markets; only 14.8% of the
British population as of February 2023, an estimated 16.8% of Danish population as of December
31, 2023, and 13.2% of the Swiss population as of February 2022 (Source: OC&C Report); and

- evidence that penetration can reach or exceed 20% in more mature markets, such as in the US,
Sweden and Norway (Source: OC&C Report).

We believe that we are ideally positioned to capitalize on this substantial market penetration opportunity
as market leader in the United Kingdom, Denmark and Switzerland with a long, successful track record
of opening new gyms and rapidly growing membership, revenue and profitability. As more sites are
rolled out, gym penetration is projected to reach 17% in the United Kingdom by February 2028 (Source:
_OC&C Report)._

Furthermore, smaller, less well-capitalized value operators will, we believe, seek to exit sites rather than
reinvest or recommit to leases when facing competition. In continental Europe, growth will also come
from improvements to our existing sites, such as by reducing costs through operational efficiencies,
reequipping and reinvesting in our core sites and reconfiguring and consolidating our estate, rather than
solely from new site roll-out.

Finally, we seek to establish ourselves as the clear number one gym operator and maintain our position
as the leading value fitness operator in each of our core markets. In the UK and Denmark, we are by a
considerable distance the largest operator by volume of sites and membership. Furthermore, in the UK
we are the largest fitness brand with un-paralleled levels of consumer awareness and consideration.

**_Continue to lead in technology, innovation and operational excellence_**

We plan to continue leading in technology, innovation and operational excellence in a number of ways,
including:

- _Investing in our industry—leading technology platform—we continue to invest in our technology_
platform. The “front end” consists of both websites and mobile applications, where our members
can book classes, pay for their memberships and other ancillary services. The “back end” includes
all the investments made to continue to develop leading edge revenue and product management as
well as big data, BI and automated performance management applications. In all cases, we are
investing to ensure we can deploy similar technology capability in all of our geographies and
languages. We believe that our data and analytics model is best in class. As the fitness industry
increasingly converges with the digital sector, we believe that our technology platform allows our
members to more easily access and purchase our services, which helps us attract and retain
members. Additionally, our technology-enabled platform allows us to analyze user-specific data,
which in turn supports our operational performance. This allows our management to better control

10


-----

all aspects of our pricing strategy, product development and promotional activities. Furthermore,
the development of our technology is ongoing, and we plan to continue to utilize technology in
order to further reduce costs and improve efficiencies.

  - We believe that an “omni-channel” approach to fitness is increasingly expected by consumers,
and therefore we plan to continue to invest in our digital and connected offering and will
further deploy our own and third-party resources to develop software and content to deliver
our digital proposition.

  - Our approach seeks to serve a broad range of consumer needs by creating digital enablement
for members to get more out of their workout, whether at home or in the gym. This ranges
from simple digital workout classes for beginners to more sophisticated training programs
using best-in-class content from around the world. To optimize our personal training offering,
we also plan to create digital tools to facilitate the process of finding and interacting with our
large network of fitness professionals. We continue to use our scale and expertise to find
innovative means of using our digital capability to allow members to get the most out of their
workouts as well as measure, track and reward their progress.

- _Driving Average Revenue Per Member— we take a multi-layered approach to increasing ARPM_
by:

  - _Developing new commercial products—we have implemented and continue to develop new_
attendance/membership options to attract certain types of new members to our gyms and
increase our fee yields while consistently offering excellent value for money. For example,
we have continued to see an increase across our gyms in penetration of our premium
membership and bolt-on products, which include benefits such as the ability to pre-book
classes on a priority basis or obtain multi-site access and typically cost about £5 to £10 more
than a “Core” membership option on average and about £3 to £8 more for specific bolt-on
elements, respectively.

  - _Price progression—we have a sophisticated price management model, which utilizes variable_
pricing for our membership products based on local market demand and dynamics for each
site. Our operational experts tailor pricing to specific local markets and monitor and change
the specific prices over time as the market and its competition evolve. In turn, this allows us
to monitor member enrollment, manage capacity and maximize revenue and returns. For
example, in January 2023, we implemented a price rise in Denmark which resulted in ARPM
for the Group, as at June 30, 2023, increasing over 4% year-over-year to £24.55 from £23.68,
driving a 16.7% revenue growth in the six months ended June 30, 2023 when compared to the
same period ended June 30, 2022.

  - _Ensuring promotional investment is optimized and ARPM leakage is minimized—the value_
fitness market responds well to promotional activity, but it is crucial that this is managed
efficiently as otherwise excess value leakage takes place. We use our increasingly
sophisticated technology platform to target promotional investment at the right time for the
right duration, in the right places and using the right mechanics. We measure the true
efficiency and effectiveness of investments carefully so that plans can be optimized.

  - _Increasing ancillary sales per visit—ancillary sales are part of our initiative to increase_
ARPM. For example, we offer sports and energy drinks and protein snacks for purchase
through on-site vending machines.

  - _Optimizing site capacity—we seek to optimize the capacity utilization of our existing gyms_
where this is possible and viable. Capacity optimization can involve the physical extension of
gyms, or the redesign of certain aspects of gyms to eliminate site-specific utilization
bottlenecks, such as the substitution of low utilization equipment, or the installation of
additional automated entry portals or access gates to increase capacity.

11


-----

  - _Marketing and CRM—we have strengthened our marketing approaches and we take an_
increasingly sophisticated and data-driven approach to membership acquisition and retention.
Our brand awareness is strong but has further room for significant growth in the context of
our large estate of gyms. We utilize channels, such as television advertising and social media,
to increase brand awareness and drive membership growth. Additionally, our industry-leading
“front end” technology platform, including our mobile apps and websites, remain a low-cost,
high volume membership acquisition and marketing tool.

  - _Development of new sales channels and cross marketing—we are leveraging our nationwide_
scale across our key markets to identify opportunities to partner and enter into commercial
arrangements with large corporations, health insurance providers and employee benefit
portals that have the potential to deliver incremental membership volumes.

  - _Maintaining a rigorous focus on cost containment—our ability to offer low membership fees_
and generate strong unit economics and ROCEs is underpinned by our low-cost operating
model. As a result, we are focused on optimizing and controlling gym-level operating costs,
as well as Initial Capital Investment Costs. These costs are controlled centrally, and we intend
to continue to leverage our growing scale in order to achieve more favorable purchasing terms
with third-party suppliers, service providers and contractors. In addition, we are pursuing a
number of ongoing operational efficiency projects, such as energy saving initiatives, to
minimize future gym-level cost increases and improve returns.

  - _Capture full value of embedded value tailwind—following our return to 2019 UK revenue_
levels, we believe that we are well-positioned to drive strong performance in the future based
on our systematic and carefully managed approach to site enhancements and implementation
of our operational and pricing model in both our core estate and new site openings.

Management has successfully contained costs at the operating level, with cost inflation of only 0.5%
over the three year period from 2019 to 2022 on a like-for-like basis. Our structurally low operating
costs delivers and supports our gym site EBITDA margin of over 30%.

Furthermore, continued efforts from management on procurement and operating efficiencies are such
that operating cost inflation for 2023, compared to 2022, is expected to be contained below 5%, which
will largely be offset by yield progression, due to operational efficiencies in the period.

In particular, management has successfully focused on containing energy and utility costs, now and
through the end of 2024, as a result of obtaining future supply contracts fixing energy prices at moderate
rates, including future supply contracts for an estimated 90% of likely supply needs. This, together with
significant resources deployed on an initiative to reduce energy consumption across the Group by up to
20% over the next 12 to 24 months, means that energy cost increases across the Group are expected to
be limited to between £5 million and £8 million for 2024, when compared to 2022.

**_Apply PureGym operational excellence/best practices throughout our portfolio_**

We have a track record of successfully integrating acquired portfolios and driving value from such
acquisitions. Our acquisition of LA Fitness in 2015 (net 31 sites acquired) and Soho Gyms in 2018 (net
nine sites acquired) are good examples of this. In both instances, we have seen significant value creation
and performance uplifts. Following the acquisition of LA Fitness, we created significant value and
performance uplifts through active intervention, including implementing our technology platform,
operating model, performance management, refurbishment and cost synergies, which resulted in
doubling EBITDA from £10 million to £20 million post-acquisition. With respect to our acquired sites
in continental Europe, we have substantially rebranded the businesses and have implemented all of the
above.

In markets, such as Denmark, where we are targeting a growth in margin, EBITDA growth will derive
from improvements in the business rather than new site roll-out. The key levers to improve profitability

12


-----

and margin are cost reduction (involving, inter alia, reductions in per-site operating costs), revenue
growth (driven by a simplified product range and roll-out of our variable pricing model), estate
rationalization (including a transition to a more focused, higher quality and more profitable estate that
is sustainable into the future) and estate upgrades, such as a comprehensive physical and digital refresh
and implementation of the PureGym SmartSuite (with a new website, mobile app, marketing
automation, changed ways of working and business rules).

**_Expand in existing markets and through franchising opportunities_**

We plan to expand in our existing markets through site roll-out, but also believe that as a scaled player
with a ready-to-deploy, technology-driven value model, we can successfully expand in markets beyond
our current areas of presence, organically or via acquisitions or franchising. Overall, through a
combination of new corporate-owned and franchised operated sites, we believe we could potentially
grow our estate to approximately 1000 to 2000 new sites with an estimated three to four million new
members, although this would depend on a number of factors and investment decisions relating to our
growth and entry into new markets. In our key markets, we intend to capitalize on strategically identified
local areas with whitespace in value gym offerings, and we are targeting to open 45 new corporateowned sites and 14 franchise operated sites in 2023 (with 22 new corporate-owned and seven franchise
operated sites already opened as of June 30, 2023). Additionally, we plan to capitalize on ample
whitespace in the UK and opening an estimated 300 new gyms in the long-term.

In 2021, we launched our franchise model, which brings an affordable, accessible gym proposition to
markets with limited access to such facilities and provides an exciting platform to expand the franchised
offering to other territories. Our franchise model allows us to develop our estate network across other
areas of the world, leveraging our core intellectual property and optimized operating model, and create
value through low capital intensive EBITDA growth.

We believe the opportunity for international development through franchising has the potential to be
very large. We believe franchising presents a significant growth opportunity in the medium term and
thereafter and believe that franchise unit economics can be attractive for both us and franchisees. For
example, we believe that current and prospective franchise partners could launch approximately 400
franchised sites by 2028 across the globe.

We believe that there is significant underserved demand for value fitness and gyms of the nature we
provide in the Middle East and Asia. In particular, we believe Saudi Arabia offers significant potential
for value fitness. In 2022, we entered into a regional development agreement with the Al Hokair Group
to develop a minimum of 130 franchise sites across the Middle East. As of June 30, 2023, we had 16
franchised sites currently in operation in Saudi Arabia and the UAE, excluding sites in pre-sales. We
believe that in the fullness of time the Middle Eastern franchise opportunity could be up to 300 sites.

We also believe that the North American market presents an attractive opportunity given the lack of
scaled value players other than Planet Fitness, the leading franchised player. In 2022, we opened our
first three gyms in the United States, which are corporate-owned and under the brand PureFitness, with
the aim of testing our low-cost, technology-enabled concept in a new international territory. Having
successfully tested our three corporate-owned gyms, we are now targeting to secure five to ten
franchisees as operating partners in the U.S. over the next five years who have the potential for at least
100 franchised sites, in order to expand our footprint across the U.S.

We also believe that the Japanese, South East Asian and ASEAN and Indian markets could be strong
franchise markets for us due to their large populations, including 700 million across ASEAN countries
and 1.3 billion people in India, that are largely underserved by a strong value gym operator.
Additionally, Japan has a low fitness penetration rate of 3.3% and does not have a strong value operator.
We also believe South Korea has a strong franchising market, with a population of 51 million and a
higher fitness penetration of 7%. We are actively pursuing a number of contacts and business
development opportunities in these regions. For more information on our franchise model, see “—
_Franchise Model.”_

13


-----

**_Sustainability and ESG are key priorities for us_**

Sustainability—and more broadly environmental, social and governance (“S-ESG”)-related issues—is
an important area of focus for us as concerns with climate change increase, consumers and employees
become increasingly engaged with this topic and the obligations being placed on businesses become
clearer on making progress on S-ESG issues to the satisfaction of both regulators and capital providers.

First, and foremost, we believe our business exists to provide a social good, as our core purpose—to
provide accessible, flexible and affordable fitness and activity to all—plays a vital role in not only
improving people’s health and wellbeing, but also as a route to addressing obesity, helping to prevent
illness and improving mental health. Additionally, our business is inherently sustainable as gyms are
effectively a part of the “sharing economy” and, especially in the case of low cost/high volume gyms
like ours, are a good, sustainable use of resources. Because members effectively “rent” access to the
gym facilities and equipment for the hours that they need, the equipment utilization is high and is an
efficient use of resources rather than further mass production of relevant equipment for each individual.

Notwithstanding this positive starting position, we recognize there is increased consumer awareness of
the link between societal trends and sustainability-related issues, and there is some evidence that these
trends are driving consumer demand towards companies that chose to pay more attention—and more
authentic attention—to issues in the S-ESG arena. Therefore, we believe it also makes good business
sense to be proactive in addressing S-ESG issues, as well as there being support for this from many
investors and a growing sense of the moral obligation on leading companies to play an appropriate role
in this regard.

Following engagement with key stakeholders—employees, members, investors and third-party
partners—we have identified five key focus areas in which to develop our S-ESG strategy:

- _Delivering Social Good—supporting as many people as possible to live healthier lives;_

- _Empowering People—fostering a thriving healthy team and community where everyone feels_
welcome and supported to reach their potential;

- _Energy and Emissions—reducing our carbon footprint and efficient use of resources;_

- _Waste & Circulatory—minimizing operational waste and embedding circular-by-design principles_
across our operations; and

- _Effective Corporate Governance—building an environment of trust, transparency and_
accountability for sustainable performance.

In 2022, we fast-tracked our decarbonization plans due to the emergence of the energy crisis, primarily
resulting from the Russia-Ukraine conflict which commenced in February of 2022. We have been
working with a market leading operational improvement consultant to identify and pursue opportunities
to significantly reduce energy usage per site. In doing so, we are in the process of establishing a new
“green” standard by which our operations are run, including new gym environment and temperature set
points; upgrades to LED lighting specification; control systems for better management of heating,
ventilation and air conditioning and, in some cases and where feasible, on-site renewable power
generation. A structured implementation program is underway with the objective of delivering
improved energy performance and broader environmental impact across our estate throughout 2023.
We are also continuing to develop measures of performance, targets and specific objectives for each of
the other emerging themes.

Our sustainability strategy approach to climate related risks and transition action plans are overseen by
the Risk and Sustainability Action Team (“RSAT”), which is chaired by our CEO and consists of our
Director of Strategic Sustainability and five other senior managers and executives. This committee
meets on at least a quarterly basis and oversees a prioritized program of work to address our key issues.

14


-----

The RSAT is further supported by external specialist advisers from time to time to ensure we are subject
to appropriate objective external challenges and contributions.

The RSAT reports, in writing, to the Board on a regular basis and the Board conducts an annual review
of our S-ESG strategy, progress and performance. In order to monitor our S-ESG strategy, the RSAT
prepared a climate risk register, which is regularly reviewed, and is developing S-ESG key performance
indicators. For additional details on our sustainability initiatives, see “—Sustainability, Environment,
_Social and Governance (S-ESG).”_

**The Transactions**

**_The Refinancing_**

We intend to use the proceeds from the issue of the Notes, along with cash on balance sheet, to (i)
redeem the Existing Notes in full (including paying the accrued interest), (ii) pay the applicable
redemption premium for the Existing Euro Notes and (iii) pay related fees and expenses (the
“Refinancing”). See “Use of Proceeds” and “Capitalization.” On or about the Issue Date, the Issuer
will satisfy and discharge all the Existing Notes by paying the relevant redemption price for each of the
Existing Notes plus accrued and unpaid interest thereon to the date of redemption.

**_The New Revolving Credit Facility_**

On or around the Issue Date, we expect to cancel our Existing Amended and Restated Revolving Credit
Facility and enter into the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement in the amount of £175.5 million
which is not expected to be utilized at the Issue Date. See “Description of Certain Financing
_Arrangements.”_

We refer to the Offering, the Refinancing, including the redemption of the Existing Notes, the entry
into the New Revolving Credit Facilities Agreement and the application of the use of proceeds as set
out in the section “Use of Proceeds” as the “Transactions.” Please see “Use of Proceeds,” “Description
_of Certain Financing Arrangements” and “Description of the Notes.”_

**Our Principal Shareholders**

As of the Issue Date, our principal shareholder, LGP (together with minority co-investors), holds
approximately 77% of the issued ordinary shares of Pinnacle Topco Limited, our ultimate parent.
Existing and legacy management and certain corporate ambassadors together hold approximately 23%
of the ordinary issued shares of Pinnacle Topco Limited, with certain of such management shareholders
able to vote up to 20% of the ordinary shares in aggregate.

As of the Issue Date, investment vehicles managed and/or advised by KKR hold £300 million
convertible preferred equity shares of Pinnacle Topco Limited through investment vehicle KKR Fitness
Aggregator L.P. KKR Fitness Aggregator L.P.’s convertible preferred equity shares may, in certain
circumstances, be converted into ordinary shares.

Founded in 1989 and based in Los Angeles, LGP is a leading private equity investment firm with $70
billion of assets under management. As one of the largest single-office private equity firms globally,
LGP has made over 140 investments since its founding with an aggregate purchase price of over $250
billion. LGP invests in market leading companies across a range of industries. LGP seeks to back
companies that are leaders in their respective industries, have robust growth potential and are led by
exceptional management teams.

LGP has delivered consistently strong returns over its 30-year history, including in the fitness sector, in
which LGP has invested $1.4 billion since 2010 in companies including Equinox, Life Time Fitness,
PureGym and Pure International. Other select current and prior LGP investments include 1-800
Contacts, BJs, Caliber Collision, Lakeshore, Mister Car Wash, Shake Shack, SunAuto Tire & Service,
Troon, Velvet Taco, Whole Foods and Zaxby’s.

Founded in 1976, KKR is a leading global investment firm with $519 billion in assets under
management as of June 30, 2023. KKR benefits from a truly global presence, with 24 offices across
four continents, employing an experienced team of over 750 investment professionals. KKR has
completed equity transactions of over $700 billion in value and acted as a lender to over 1,800
companies globally. KKR has a long track record of partnership and minority deals and has invested or
committed over $27 billion of its own capital to its own funds and deals.

Based on preliminary results derived from unaudited management monthly accounts and other
information currently available, we estimate that our revenue for the month ended July 31, 2023
increased to approximately £45 million from £39 million for the month ended July 31, 2022,
representing an estimated increase of approximately £6 million compared to the same period in 2022.
This increase was primarily driven by a combination of member volume (from new sites, maturation of
existing immature sites and steady recovery in mature sites) and ARPM growth.

We estimate that our Adjusted EBITDA for the month ended July 31, 2023 increased to approximately
£12 million from £9 million for the month ended July 31, 2022, representing an estimated increase of

combination of revenue growth and continued focus on cost control.

We estimate that our Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA for the month ended July 31, 2023 increased to
approximately £130 million from £108 million for the month ended July 31, 2022, representing an
estimated increase of approximately £22 million. This increase was due to the factors outlined above.

In addition, we opened 4 new corporate-owned gyms in July 2023, increasing our total number of gyms,
including both corporate-owned and franchise operated gyms, as at July 31, 2023 to 584. Our members
for the month ended July 31, 2023 increased to approximately 1,869,000.

We estimate that our senior secured net leverage for the month ended July 31, 2023 decreased to
approximately 4.9x from 5.3x for the month ended July 31, 2022. This decrease was primarily due to
our increase in Run Rate Adjusted EBITDA and increase in cash on balance sheet for the month.

(1) We define “Mature gyms” as corporate-owned gyms that have been open for two full financial years or more as at the reporting date.

(2) We define total number of members as the total number of active members in corporate owned gyms, including the total number of
members who have suspended (to “freeze” or have “frozen”) their memberships, but excluding “pay-as-you-go” customers, the total
number of members who have cancelled their memberships and the total number of pre-opening members of organic gyms that have
yet to open, as of the specified date or the end date of the relevant period.

(3) We define average number of members per gym as the average of the number of members for each gym as of the beginning of the first
month and the end of every month in that period.

(4) We define average revenue per member per month as revenue for that period divided by the number of months in that period and further
divided by the average number of members during that period. The average number of members during that period is calculated as the
average of the number of members at corporate owned gyms as of the beginning of the first month and the end of every month in that
period.

for the financial period as indicators of our performance, or as alternatives to operating cash flows as a measure of our liquidity. Our
management uses these measures to assess our operating performance. In addition, we believe that similar measures are commonly
used by investors. See “Presentation of Financial and Other Data.”

(6) We define “EBITDA” as profit or loss for a certain period before income tax expense, net finance cost, depreciation and impairment

(7) We define “Adjusted EBITDA” as profit or loss for a certain period before income tax expense, net finance cost, depreciation and
impairment of property, plant and equipment and right of use assets, amortization of intangible fixed assets, profit/loss on disposal of
property, plant and equipment, profit/loss on lease modifications, exceptional administrative expenses and other adjustments, after
adding back Pre-Opening costs and share based payment charges and subtracting the Cash Rent Adjustment.

relating to the settlement of a lease exit in the UK which totaled £10.9 million, of which £5.0 million was recognized in the year ended
December 31, 2020 and £5.9 million in the year ended December 31, 2021. Also in the year ended December 31, 2021, £10.9 million
of costs were incurred in the exploration of, and preparation for capital fund raising options, and costs of £0.7 million were incurred
relating to the exploration of expansion opportunities in the U.S. In the year ended December 31, 2022, a £1.4 million credit, as
compared to the £1.1 million credit in 2021, was recognized in relation to VAT recoverable on exceptional expenses in previous periods.
For the six months ended June 30, 2023, exceptional items included costs related to the rebrand of our Danish operations to the PureGym
brand.

(b) Refers to the net impact of various one-off items not included in “exceptional administrative expenses.”

(c) Pre-Opening Costs represents the total of all gym site operating costs incurred during the pre-opening periods of gyms in that period.
Pre-Opening Costs primarily consist of staff and marketing costs.

(d) Cash rent adjustments represents the deduction of the cash rent payable during the period which otherwise was not reflected in EBITDA
(as reported on a post-IFRS 16 basis). From 2021 onwards, the Cash Rent Adjustment excludes the cash impact of COVID-19 rent
deferments. Therefore, Adjusted EBITDA more closely reflects the underlying trading results of the Group for the period.

(e) Head Office Costs for a given period are defined as all non-gym specific costs, other than depreciation and amortization, related to the
operation of head office functions in that period.

(f) Fitness World pre-acquisition Adjusted EBITDA reflects Fitness World’s Adjusted EBITDA for the first 13 days of trading in 2020
prior to the Group’s acquisition on January 14, 2020.

(g) Run-Rate Adjustment is an adjustment made to those gyms which are less than three years old at the end of the reporting period. These
adjustments replace the Adjusted EBITDA earned by these sites in the last twelve month period with the projected Adjusted EBITDA
for their third year of operation. Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA therefore seeks to reflect the anticipated mature Adjusted EBITDA
potential of those gyms which were trading at the end of the relevant period. See “Business—Key Strengths—High cash flow generative
_profile underpinned by exceptional profitability and positive working capital cash inflows.”_

We believe that our gyms generate Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA at a mature rate at month 24, therefore months 25 to 36 represent the
first full year of mature EBITDA performance. We believe these run-rate adjustments are appropriate because, based on our experience
and the actual performance of gyms open fewer than two years, the first two years of operation are unrepresentative of run-rate trading.
Management has confidence in these gyms achieving their estimated run-rate profitability, given the consistent and predictable rampup delivered by the gym cohorts in previous years. These adjustments to EBITDA are presented for informational purposes only and
do not purport to present what EBITDA would have been had newly opened gyms been open for the entire period nor does it purport
to project EBITDA for any future period. The assumptions underlying the adjustments are based on our current estimates and they
involve risks, uncertainties and other factors that may cause actual results or performance to be materially different from anticipated
future results or performance expressed or implied by such adjustments. See “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our business—Certain
_non-IFRS measures such as Run-Rate Adjusted EBITDA incorporate forward-looking estimates that may differ from actual results.”_
