_Factors—Risks relating to our business—We may be forced to close gyms temporarily or other adverse_
_consequences could result due to unforeseen circumstances.”_

Despite the significant impact of government mandated lockdowns on our day-to-day operations, our
business returned to profitability in May 2021 following the reopening of our estate. In December 2021,
we agreed a £300 million equity investment from global investment firm, KKR, which completed in
January 2022 and materially increased the Group’s available liquidity. For the year ended December
31, 2022, revenue was £476.4 million compared to £302.4 million in the year ended December 31,
2021. In addition to no loss of revenue due to government mandated site closures relating to COVID19, this change was also due to increases in the average revenue per member resulting from measured
price increases in existing gyms, an increase in members from 1.5 million in 2021 to 1.7 million in 2022
and the opening of 45 new corporate-owned gyms in year ended December 31, 2022.

As of and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, our revenue was £515.3 million, an increase of
17% compared to revenue of £442.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2019 (on 2019 Adjusted
Combined Basis). Group membership stands at 1.9 million members as of June 30, 2023, an increase
of over 9% compared to the closing members of 1.7 million as of December 31, 2019 (on a 2019
Adjusted Combined Basis). In the UK, like-for-like revenue in the month ended June 30, 2023 was
101% as compared to the same period in 2019, while like-for-like membership numbers were only 87%
for the same comparative period. This was primarily due to yield improvements.

While the trends observed in the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020 demonstrated our resilience
at that point in time, there can be no assurance that our recovery following any future pandemics or
macroeconomic turmoil would be comparably robust. The effect of any future pandemics or
macroeconomic turmoil on our business and the wider fitness industry will ultimately depend on a
number of factors, including, but not limited to, the duration and severity of the outbreak and the length
of time it takes for demand and pricing to return and for normal economic and operating conditions to
resume. Furthermore, there can be no assurances that we will be able to effectively implement cost
reduction initiatives or receive government aid or support from our stakeholders, in the future. For
additional detail, see “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our business—The effect of any future pandemics
_could materially negatively impact the operations of our business and, therefore, our financial position,_
_due to many factors, some of which are beyond our control,” “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our_
_business—Economic factors or a change in consumer preferences and discretionary spending, which_
_are uncertain and largely beyond our control, could negatively impact our membership figures, which_
_could adversely affect our revenue” and “Risk Factors—Risks relating to our business—We may be_
_forced to close gyms temporarily or other adverse consequences could result due to unforeseen_
_circumstances.”_

**_Roll out of new gyms_**

New gym openings have been a significant driver of our growth during the periods under review and
our roll out strategy has had, and is expected to continue to have, a significant effect on our results of
operations. We opened 18 new corporate-owned gyms in 2020, 25 in 2021, 45 in 2022 and 22 in the six
months ended June 30, 2023. In addition, in January 2020, the Group’s estate increased by 222 gyms
as a result of the Fitness World acquisition (excluding 17 sites in Poland, subsequently sold in December
2020).

83


-----

The charts below show the performance of new UK site openings since January 2022, with member
numbers ramping up ahead of our pre-COVID-19 year three target.

_Source: Management data._

**_Pre-opening period_**

Prior to opening, each new corporate-owned gym typically undergoes a two to three-month long
pre-opening period following commencement of the lease. During this period, construction of the gym
is completed, a significant amount of marketing is conducted and discounted membership offers are
typically made to attract new members. Pre-Opening Costs were £3.3 million in the year ended
December 31, 2021, compared to £1.6 million in the year ended December 31, 2020 and largely
consisted of staff costs and marketing expenses. The increase was partly due to the increased number
of new corporate-owned gyms opened in each period, but also due to the fact that some new gyms were
prevented from opening for longer periods than normal due to the impact of COVID-19.

Pre-Opening Costs were £4.8 million in the year ended December 31, 2022 compared to £3.3 million
in the year ended December 31, 2021. This increase was primarily due to the increased number of new
corporate-owned gym openings in 2022 which was 45 compared to 25 in 2021. Pre-Opening Costs were
£2.4 million in the six months ended June 30, 2023 compared to £2.0 million in the six months ended
June 30, 2022. This increase was primarily due to the increased number of new corporate-owned gym
openings in the six months ended June 30, 2023 which was 22 compared to 17 in the six months ended
June 30, 2022.

Average Pre-Opening Cost per UK site for the year ended December 31, 2022 was £102,000 and for
the six months ended June 30, 2023 was £91,000. These are slightly higher than the typical pre-opening
cost expected for a new UK site of approximately £74,000 due to one off delays at a small number of
sites during those periods.

**_Maturity profile_**

Once a new corporate-owned gym opens, our membership base generally increases rapidly in the first
three to six months eventually reaching mature levels after approximately 24 months.

Revenue per member also increases as members who join post-opening typically pay higher monthly
membership fees than those on pre-opening offers. Growth in revenue per member is also supported by
the expiration of pre-opening offers, which generally terminate between three and 12 months after
opening, when members who remain on these offers receive an automatic price uplift. Together, these
factors typically drive increases in revenue and result in growth in Gym Site Adjusted EBITDA as a
significant proportion of gym operating and property costs are fixed.

84


-----

We defined a Mature Gym as a corporate-owned gym that has been open for two full financial years or
more as at the reporting date. We ordinarily consider a gym as a mature gym at the end of its second
year of operation, as a gym’s EBITDA tends to be substantially mature after 24 months, whereas during
the first 24 months we usually see an increase in a gym’s EBITDA. Typically, a gym’s third year is the
first full year during which it delivers annual Gym EBITDA of a mature level. For example, we consider
a gym that opened in August 2020 a Mature Gym for the year ended December 31, 2022, although its
EBITDA only tends to stabilize after August 2022, and, therefore, accordingly, the period from January
1, 2023 to December 31, 2023 would be the first full financial year during which that gym delivers an
annual Gym EBITDA of a mature level.

**_Initial Capital Investment_**

We incur capital costs to construct and fit out new corporate-owned gyms. For the year ended December
31, 2022 and for the six months ended June 30, 2023, the Average Initial Capital Investment for
corporate-owned gyms in UK (both Mature Gyms and New Gyms) was £1.2 million.

**_Membership volumes_**

We derive substantially all of our revenue from monthly membership fees and joining fees paid by our
members. Membership fees and joining fees represented 90.4% of our total revenue for the year ended
December 31, 2020, 88.8% of our total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2021, 89.1% of our
total revenue for the year ended December 31, 2022 and 89.1% for the six months ended June 30, 2023.
Accordingly, our revenue is significantly dependent on membership volumes. Membership volumes are
generally affected by numerous factors, including the total number of gyms in operation, the prices the
gyms charge, the sizes and locations of our gyms, competitive dynamics in the value gym market and
seasonality, amongst others. In 2020 and 2021, our membership was significantly impacted by the
lockdowns imposed as a result of COVID-19. See “—Impact of COVID-19.”

Our membership has grown substantially over the six-month period ending June 30, 2023, with closing
membership standing at approximately 1,855,000 members, compared to 1,451,000 members,
1,535,000 members and 1,665,000 members, as of December 31, 2020, 2021 and 2022, respectively.
The increase was driven by the steady recovery in volume in the core estate following the lifting of
lockdown restrictions in May 2021, the maturation of existing New Gyms and new sites opened in the
period.

**_Membership pricing_**

In addition to volume, our revenue is also dependent on the prices we charge. We operate a dynamic
pricing model with the objective of maximizing each site’s revenue. To this end, membership fee and
joining fee rates are set on an individual gym basis and take into account a number of factors such as a
gym’s membership level, its utilization profile, its capacity, the demographic profile of its local
catchment and the degree of local competition, amongst others.

Average Revenue per Member per Month for the Group was £24.61 for the six months ended June 30,
2023 compared to £23.84, £16.51 and £13.98 for the years ended December 31, 2022, 2021, and 2020,
respectively. In 2020 and 2021, growth was primarily as a result of the impact of site closures due to
COVID-19, while in 2022 and 2023, the growth was primarily driven by price progression.

**_Danish transformation plan_**

In connection with the integration and rebrand of our Danish sites to our core PureGym business model,
we implemented a strategic transformation plan with a commercial focus on active revenue and yield
management. We believe that our performance metrics demonstrate that PureGym has developed the
leading operating model, which is, and we believe in the future will continue to be, a significant driver
of growth in our Danish segment.

In the years ended December 31, 2020, 2021, 2022, we operated 179, 174, and 169 sites in Denmark,
respectively, and in the six months ended June 30, 2022 and 2023 we operated 169 and 168 sites in
Denmark. This reduction in sites is a key component of our Danish estate optimization strategy, in
which the Danish estate is being consolidated to provide a higher quality and more profitable estate that
is sustainable into the future. In the majority of cases, such site consolidation is not expected to result
in significant loss of members, as members will be transferred to neighboring PureGym sites.

86


-----

For the six months ended June 30, 2023, revenue in Denmark increased by 7.2% when compared to
revenue for the six months ended June 30, 2022. This increase was primarily driven by a price increase
in January 2023 combined with the incorporation of our leading PureGym operating model.

Following comprehensive analysis of our sites across Denmark, we expect to further optimize our estate
to between 130 and 140 sites, which we believe will lead to reduced costs, higher Average Revenue Per
Member and increased EBITDA in the future.

**_Operating Costs_**

_Low-cost gym operating model_

We employ a low-cost, technology-enabled gym operating model, which enables us to offer a
compelling customer value proposition while simultaneously delivering strong operating margins and
profitability.

The majority of site operating costs are controlled centrally within each geography and senior
management is focused on leveraging scale and implementing other initiatives to control costs and
improve efficiencies. Within each geography, site operating costs, other than property costs, are
generally consistent across all of our gyms within that geography and do not typically vary significantly
between sites. Accordingly, site operating costs as a percentage of revenue for a Mature Gym are
substantially lower than for a New Gym.

Our low-cost gym, technology-enabled operating model benefits from having low personnel costs,
property and space flexibility, low energy intensity, pricing sophistication, purchasing scale, the ability
to invest, high brand awareness and leading marketing expertise. See “Business—Strategy—Continue
_to lead in technology, innovation and operational excellence.”_

Site operating costs for the six months ended June 30, 2023 of £175.9 million have increased from
£151.4 million for the six months ended June 30, 2022. This reflects the increased number of gyms in
the estate, combined with an average inflationary uplift of approximately 5%.

Site operating costs for the year ended December 31, 2022 of £312.8 million have increased from £213.9
million and £220.5 million for the years ended December 31, 2021 and 2020, respectively. These
increases are due in part to the increased number of gyms in the estate, combined with the above 0.5%
inflationary increase, but also due to 2020 and 2021 both being severely impacted by the COVID-19
lockdown periods, during which management took action to minimize costs incurred to the business
whilst closed and the Group benefited from various government COVID-19 support packages,
including the furlough scheme in the UK and the fixed cost compensation scheme in Denmark.

See “Business—Strategy—Continue to lead in technology, innovation and operational excellence.”

_Head Office Costs_

We have made substantial investments in Head Office Costs over recent years to facilitate continued
innovation and differentiation, to gain more control over certain key business functions, such as IT, and
to deliver the management and technology infrastructure to support our enlarged estate and future
growth plans. These investments have included hiring additional staff as well as making investments in
management processes and IT systems to build and maintain an industry-leading technology platform.
For the year ended December 31, 2022, head office costs were £68.5 million, an increase from £54.0
million for the year ended December 31, 2021 and from £38.0 million in the year ended December 31,
2020. These increases are due in part to the investments detailed above, but also due to 2020 and 2021
both being severely impacted by the COVID-19 lockdown periods, during which management took
action to minimize costs incurred to the business whilst closed and the Group benefited from various
government COVID-19 support packages, including the furlough scheme in the UK and the fixed cost
compensation scheme in Denmark.

87


-----

**_Seasonality_**

We experience a small degree of seasonality. The majority of our membership growth takes place in
January, February, September and October. Seasonality is generally positively driven by consumers’
desire to improve their fitness at the start of the year and the start of new university/school terms, and
negatively driven by Christmas and summer holidays. We generally focus our marketing spend around
peak joining periods, particularly during the January/February period.

**_Tax_**

We recognize expected tax liabilities based on an estimation of the likely taxes due, which requires
significant judgment as to the ultimate tax treatment of certain items. Following recent losses endured
as a result of COVID-19, we recorded income tax credits of £20.8 million, £19.7 million and £34.0
million during the years ended December 31, 2020, 2021 and 2022, respectively. In the six-month
period to June 30, 2023, we recorded income tax expense of £0.4 million due to the expected utilization
of deferred tax assets in the period.

**Significant factors affecting comparability of our results of operations**

**_Impact of COVID-19_**

In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain financial and other operating data as of and for the
year ended December 31, 2019. In addition to its usefulness as regards its historical performance, this
data represents the ordinary course operations of our business before the impact of COVID 19 and the
acquisition of Fitness World in January 2020 (unless otherwise stated, on a 2019 Adjusted Combined
Basis).

We have also presented financial and other operating data as of and for years ended December 31, 2020
and 2021, which represent the impact on our business of the acquisition of Fitness World and COVID
19. Accordingly, our financial condition and results of operations in 2020 and 2021 will differ when
compared to the other historical financial condition and results of operations presented in this
discussion. Furthermore, we have also presented financial and other operating data as of and for the
year ended December 31, 2022, as of and for the twelve months ended June 30, 2023 and as of and for
the six months ended June 30, 2022 and June 30, 2023, which represents a return to ordinary course of
operations in our business after the impact of COVID-19 for most of our results of operation.

See “—Significant factors affecting our results of operations—Impact of COVID-19.”

**_Acquisitions and Divestments_**

_Acquisitions_

Organic growth is the bedrock of our growth strategy, with acquisitions considered only when there is
a clear strategic rationale and a high level of confidence in being earnings accretive within
approximately two years. M&A activity has had a positive effect on our results of operations, which is
evidenced by our acquisition of LA Fitness in 2015 (net 31 sites acquired) and Soho Gyms in 2018 (net
9 sites acquired). In both instances, we have seen significant value creation and performance uplifts.

On January 14, 2020, we also acquired Fitness World’s 239 gym estate spanning across Denmark,
Switzerland and Poland, for a consideration of DKK 2,037.1 million (£233.4 million), and the
repayment of DKK 1,033.1 million (£118.0 million) of outstanding Fitness World indebtedness. We
acquired Fitness World because it was a strong business with very similar characteristics to PureGym.
The Fitness World Acquisition provided us with a number of operational, financial and strategic
benefits, such as increased scale in procurement, greater scale and diversification, including a stable
cash generating business with opportunities for further expansion and critical mass in international
activities.

88


-----

Due to COVID-19, full integration, consolidation and management coordination was largely halted for
two years. However, following this period, we resumed the integration and coordination of the
businesses. Further work is underway to restore and drive forward the performance and profitability of
the acquired Danish and Swiss businesses and this is a key focus for management.

The financial data of the Group as of and for the year ended December 31, 2020 presented herein include
Fitness World from its date of acquisition, January 14, 2020.

_Divestments_

On December 15, 2020, the Polish subsidiary, Fitness World sp. z o. o. (acquired in January 2020 as
part of the Fitness World Group) (“Fitness World Poland”) was sold following a strategic decision to
withdraw from the Polish market. The exit from Poland in late 2020 had no material impact on the
Group, and it was not significant in terms of either revenue or profits. The results of Fitness World
Poland are reported as a discontinued operation for the year ended December 31, 2020.

**Description of key income statement items**

**_Revenue_**

Revenue primarily comprises monthly membership fees paid by members, including fees paid by
members who freeze their memberships, additional fees for value-add options, such as premium
membership options and non-refundable joining fees paid by new members in the period. Monthly
membership fees are recognized evenly over the month on a daily basis with deferred revenue recorded
at the month end for any revenue that is to be recognized in the following month. Joining fees are
recognized in the month of receipt, with the exception of joining fees received from members who sign
up during the pre-opening period of a new gym, which are recognized as revenue in the month the
relevant gym opens. We also generate revenue from day-pass sales, vending sales, marketing
contributions from suppliers, direct debit bounce fees, rent from personal trainers and other ancillary
activities. Revenue is stated excluding value added tax and other sales-related taxes.

89


-----

**_Cost of sales_**

Cost of sales represents the cost arising in connection with the generation of revenue from the “vending
and consumables income” and “other revenue” revenue streams, including the cost of inventories sold.

**_Other administrative expenses_**

Other administrative expenses comprise the costs incurred in administering our operations, including
employee costs, marketing costs, property costs, other operating costs, head office costs, depreciation
and impairment of property, plant and equipment and amortization and impairment of intangible assets.
Gains and losses on disposals of property, plant and equipment are also included in other administrative
expenses. Employee costs consist of wages and salaries, social security and pension costs. Marketing
costs comprise expenditure relating to attracting new members and retaining existing members.
Property costs include rates, services charges, and other costs related to property but exclude property
lease rental costs as these are no longer accounted for within Other administrative expenses under IFRS
16, _Leases. Under IFRS 16 Leases, property lease costs now feature in the Income statement as_
depreciation charged on right of use assets and finance charges, on the unwind of the discounted lease
liabilities. Other operating costs comprise repairs, maintenance, cleaning, insurance, security, utilities
expenses and other costs.

Head office costs comprise costs that are not allocated to our gyms and are generally incurred in
administrating our estate and our business, including central and regional support staff costs and their
associated administration costs, technology and website maintenance costs, professional fees and other
costs. The largest component of head office costs is employee costs.

Depreciation of property, plant and equipment relates to depreciation of fixtures and fittings, leasehold
improvements, fitness equipment and right of use assets. Capital costs are depreciated over six years
for fixtures, fittings and fitness equipment, three to fifteen years for leasehold improvements and the
life of the lease for leasehold costs and right of use assets. Initial Capital Investment is generally
depreciated over a blended average useful life of nine years while refurbishment capital spend is
generally depreciated over a blended average useful life of six years. Amortization includes
amortization of intangible assets.

**_Exceptional administrative expenses_**

Exceptional administrative expenses include items that are material in size and unusual or infrequent in
nature, such as one-off costs related to the COVID-19 pandemic, the exploration of a capital raising or
expansion opportunity and restructuring costs incurred in relation to a reset of the Danish head office
cost base. The separate reporting of exceptional administrative expenses helps provide an indication of
our underlying performance.

**_Net finance costs_**

Net finance costs are finance costs net of finance income. Finance costs represent the interest and
charges (accrued or paid) associated with bank loans and overdrafts under the Amended and Restated
Revolving Credit Facility, the Existing Notes, the preference shares, finance leases, foreign exchange
losses, amortization of any fees associated with the raising of finance that have been capitalized and
costs associated with the unwinding of property lease liabilities on a post-IFRS 16 basis, which are
recognized using the effective interest method.

Finance income consists of interest (accrued or paid) on cash held at the bank, income from IFRS 16
sub-leases and additionally, exceptional non-cash finance income arising upon the refinancing of our
bridge facility (entered into in connection with the Fitness World acquisition in January 2020) with the
issuance of our Existing Euro Notes in November 2020.

90


-----

**_Income tax (charge)/credit_**

Income tax (charge)/credit comprises current and deferred tax. Current tax is the expected tax payable
or receivable on the taxable income or loss for the year, using tax rates enacted or substantively enacted
at the reporting date, and any adjustment to tax payable or receivable in respect of previous years.
Deferred tax is recognized in respect of temporary differences between the carrying amounts of assets
and liabilities for financial reporting purposes and the amounts used for taxation purposes. Deferred tax
assets are recognized for unused tax losses, unused tax credits and deductible temporary differences to
the extent that it is probable that future taxable profits will be available against which they can be used.

**Qualitative and quantitative disclosures concerning market risk**

In the ordinary course of business, the Group is exposed to a variety of market risks including credit
risk, liquidity risk, interest rate risk and foreign exchange risk. The Group monitors and manages these
risks as part of our overall risk management and seeks to minimize potential adverse effects on our
financial position and performance. Exposures to market risk are discussed in more detail in note 21 of
the consolidated financial statements as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022, included
elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum. This discussion does not address other risks to which we are
exposed in the ordinary course of business, such as operational risks. See “Risk Factors.”

**_Market risk_**

Market risk is the risk that the fair value of future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate
because of changes in market prices. The key market risks affecting the Group are interest rate risk and
foreign exchange rate risk. Financial instruments affected by market risk include certain borrowings
and deposits. Financial instruments affected by exchange rate risk include the Existing Euro Notes. At
June 30, 2023, the €490 million Euro Notes had a carrying amount of £413.3 million based on an
amortized cost of €480.7 million and an exchange rate of €0.8598 to £1.00. As of the year ended
December 31, 2022, the Existing Euro Notes had a carrying amount of £423.5 million based on an
amortized cost of €478.1 million and an exchange rate of €0.886 to £1.00. Had the exchange rate at
December 31, 2022 been 10% higher, then our loss for the year would have increased by £42.3 million.
Foreign exchange rate risk on our Existing Euro Notes is partially mitigated through the cash flows and
value of our investments in subsidiaries denominated in Danish Krone, which is pegged against the
Euro. However, the effectiveness of this mitigation depends on the relative value of our Danish
operations.

**_Interest rate risk_**

Interest rate risk is the risk that the fair value of future cash flows of a financial instrument will fluctuate
because of changes in market interest rates. Exposure to the risk of changes in market interest rates
relates primarily to the Group’s bank borrowings with floating interest rates.

As at June 30, 2023 and December 31, 2022, the Group had 100% of its borrowings in fixed rate
instruments by way of senior secured notes, amounts owed to Group undertakings and lease liabilities.
The Group has access to a £145 million Amended and Restated Revolving Credit Facility with floating
interest rates but as at June 30, 2023 and December 31, 2022, the facility was undrawn.

**_Liquidity risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that the Group will not be able to meet its financial obligations as they fall due.
Ultimate responsibility for liquidity risk management rests with the Board. Liquidity risk is managed
by continuously monitoring forecast and actual cash flows, matching the maturity profiles of financial
assets and operational liabilities and by maintaining adequate cash reserves.

Exposures to liquidity risk are discussed in note 21 of the consolidated financial statements as of and
for the year ended December 31, 2022.

**_Credit risk_**

Credit risk is the risk of financial loss to the Group if a member or counterparty to a financial instrument
fails to meet our contractual obligations.

Principal financial assets are bank balances and cash, trade and other receivables and investments. The
credit risk on liquid funds and derivative financial instruments is minimized due to exposure being
spread over a large number of customers who generally pay by direct debit in advance. The credit risk
on liquid funds is limited because the counterparties are banks with high credit ratings assigned by
international credit-rating agencies.

**Overview of the health and fitness club market**

**_European health and fitness club market_**

The European health and fitness club market had total revenues of €28 billion as of December 2022,
almost reaching the pre-COVID-19 revenues of €28.2 billion as of December 2019 (Source:
_Deloitte/EuropeActive Report), and similarly, fitness club membership volumes have reached pre-_
COVID-19 levels and continued the previously shown consistent growth across most European
geographies, driven by structural trends towards greater consumer health awareness and high
importance, government support and promotion of fitness, as well as continued increase in gym
capacity. Over the four years from February 2015 to February 2019, gym membership in Europe was
estimated to have increased from 54 million to 65 million, which reflects an estimated CAGR of 4.7%
(Source: OC&C Report). In 2022, European memberships increased by approximately 7 million
members, or 12%, from 56 million in 2021 to 63 million. (Source: Deloitte/EuropeActive Report).

_(Source: Deloitte/EuropeActive Report)_

**_Increased focus on health and wellness_**

The COVID-19 pandemic further increased consumers’ focus on health and wellness, driving
significant growth in the frequency with which consumers exercise. Based on market research

101


-----

conducted in the UK, 88% of UK consumers showed a greater concern for their wellbeing in 2021,
compared to 84% in 2019, and consumers also consistently ranked physical exercise within their top
four most important lifestyle activities, above eating and drinking out, holidays abroad, shopping and
going to live events or movies (Source: _Deloitte/EuropeActive Report, OC&C Report)._

_Importance of Health, Wellness and Exercise: UK Case Study_

Another market survey, conducted in May 2023, indicated that 95% of UK gym users exercise at least
once a week compared to only 74% pre-COVID-19. The increased focus on health and fitness in the
UK is also driven by UK government health and fitness initiatives, including “Change4Life,” a public
health program that began in 2009 to tackle unhealthy lifestyles by encouraging exercise and healthy
eating, and a health incentives scheme where users wore wrist-worn devices and completed dietary
surveys that generated personalized health recommendations targeting physical activity and diet.

_Increased Exercise Since COVID-19 is Driving Membership Growth_

It is also worth noting the demographic differences in the fitness industry. Young adults tend to be more
committed to health and fitness and have, therefore, seen a more significant increase in exercise
frequency post-COVID-19. In a recent survey conducted in the UK in May 2023, the number of young
adults (aged 18-24) that exercised over three times a week increased to 44%, an increase of 13% from
30.6% in July 2019 and 7% higher than the 37% for all adults (Source: OC&C Report). We believe that
this trend particularly favors the Group, as our business model skews towards younger demographics.

102


-----

_Frequency of Exercise of All Adults vs Young Adults_

**_Resilience of the health and fitness club market_**

While the recent increase in the cost of living and inflationary pressures have impacted the consumer
sentiment in the UK and Europe due to the potential squeeze on disposable income, the health and
fitness club market is expected to be more resilient compared to other consumer facing sectors. The
increasing importance of health and wellness for consumers makes gym-spend less discretionary in
nature and value club operators also benefit from trade-down of the mid-market and even premium
members.

As evidenced by the market survey conducted in May 2023, gym users prioritize spending in the area
of health and fitness ahead of spending on many other areas. Only 16% of UK consumers are likely to
reduce their spending on gym membership when redistributing their budget due to income squeeze.
This is significantly below other spending buckets such as eating and drinking out, attending events,
shopping and going away on holiday.

_Gym Membership Spend is Likely to be Protected by Consumers: UK Case Study_

Within the discretionary consumer spend categories, the gym-spend is viewed as resilient through
economic downturns as it targets value-seeking consumers through attractive monthly costs and flexible
membership terms. As evidenced during the 2008-2009 financial crisis, gym spend continued to grow
despite falling GDP in the UK.

103


-----

_Resilience of Spend on Gyms is Expected Given Evidence from Last Major Recession, where Spend on_

_Gyms is Significantly Less Cyclical than Other Categories_

Furthermore, based on a survey conducted in the UK, the young demographic customers (16-29 yearsold) are less exposed to the increase of monthly cost of living when compared to the UK population as
a whole and, therefore, are less concerned about the Cost of Living Crisis (Source: OC&C Report).
This drives increased resilience in the segment as members less than 35 years old are less likely to
cancel their gym membership than those in the 35 to 54 year-old age bracket. As a result, only 22% of
our members indicate the likelihood of canceling or switching gyms in the next 12 months, which is
less than the 24% to 40% likelihood of our peers in the UK.

_<35 Y/O are Less Likely to Cancel Their Gym Membership_

**_Health and fitness club segments_**

Generally, the health and fitness club market is split into two main segments: public clubs and private
clubs. The private clubs’ segment can be further split into: (i) premium clubs; (ii) mid-market clubs and
(iii) value clubs.

Public clubs are those funded and operated by local authorities or county councils. They are typically
larger in size compared to private clubs and offer a wide variety of facilities such as sports halls, studios
and swimming pools. Some public clubs are managed or operated by private companies on behalf of
local authorities and county councils. Public clubs are generally open to members of the public on a
pay-and-play or membership basis. Private clubs are those funded and operated by commercial
enterprises, including value, mid-market and premium gym offerings. The private club market is
generally significantly larger than the public club market.

Mid-market and premium clubs are generally larger in size and usually contain a wider range of
facilities that for example include wet areas (e.g., swimming pools, spas and saunas), racquet sports
courts (e.g., tennis courts and squash courts), health and wellbeing facilities and social areas for

104


-----

members (e.g., bars and cafes). Additionally, members are often required to sign up to fixed-duration
membership contracts, which typically include early termination fees.

Mid-market and premium clubs generally have higher operating costs than value clubs due to their
larger size, high-cost sales process, increased number of facilities offered, greater number of staff (e.g.,
in-gym sales and marketing teams and fully staffed reception and refreshment areas) and higher
maintenance costs (e.g., cleaning and maintenance of wet areas).

Value clubs generally charge lower membership fees per month as compared to mid-market and
premium private clubs. Value clubs offer a more focused product that is designed for consumers who
only want to pay for and use fitness equipment (e.g., cardiovascular machines, fixed resistance
machines, free-weights and fitness studios), rather than wet facilities such as swimming pools, spas and
saunas. Members of value clubs are generally not required to sign up to fixed-duration membership
contracts and can generally cancel their memberships at any time without material financial
consequence. Often, value clubs are more tech-enabled, in order to keep operating costs low, and
generally have longer opening hours than traditional private clubs (e.g., many of our gyms are open 24hours-a-day (where available), seven-days-a-week and 365-days-a-year).

**_Growth of value club segment_**

In the global health and fitness club market, there has been a rising trend of customers moving towards
value operators and this is expected to further accelerate. In Europe, and in the UK in particular, value
operators have historically driven fitness market growth. Between February 2015 and February 2022,
value clubs accounted for 91% of member additions in Europe (based on the leading 15 operators) and
82% in the UK (Source: _Deloitte/EuropeActive Report, OC&C Report)._

As a value clubs operator, we benefit from consumers trading down from the mid-market and premium
offerings in the current market conditions. In the UK, the value segment grew by 274,000 members, an
increase of 10% from 2022 to 2023, driven by inflow of new fitness users and trade-down of 179,000
members from the mid-market and public gym operators. This also reflects that the offering of value
clubs resonates with consumers, further demonstrated by stable member value retention between
January 2020 and June 2023.

**Value clubs compared to Mid-Market and Premium clubs**

In the UK, value clubs are private clubs that generally charge £25 or less per month across the majority
of clubs in the chain and premium gyms are those that generally charge over £60 per month. Upper
mid-market gyms typically charge between £60 and £40, and lower mid-market-gyms charge less than
£40 but more than value club monthly membership fees. As of February 2023, there were 3,667 total
mid-market and premium clubs in the UK with 4.0 million total members, equivalent to an approximate
average of 755 members per mid-market club and 2,397 members per premium club (Source: OC&C
_Report)._

**Historical growth of value clubs**

The value club market has experienced rapid growth over the five years between 2015 and 2019. Since
February 2015, the number of value clubs in the UK increased from approximately 300 to

109


-----

approximately 700 as of February 2019, reflecting a CAGR of 21.0%, while the number of value club
members grew from 1.3 million to 2.8 million, reflecting a CAGR of 20.5%. Post-COVID-19 as of
February 2023, the number of value clubs is estimated to be 793 compared to 683 in February 2019,
reflecting a CAGR of 3.8%, with 3.0 million members compared to 2.8 million in 2019, reflecting a
CAGR of 1.5%. (Source: OC&C Report). While value clubs represented 9% of the total number of
health and fitness clubs in the UK as of February 2019, they represented 27% of the total number of
health and fitness club members for the same period. Post-COVID-19 as of February 2023, value clubs
represented 11% of clubs and 30% of members as value clubs have a substantially higher number of
average members per club. The largest value club operators in the UK are PureGym and The Gym
Group (Source: OC&C Report).

The private club market has historically been served primarily by mid-market and premium private
clubs. However, value clubs have made a significant entrance into the market by taking market share
from mid-market clubs and growing the overall number of private club members by attracting new
consumers to the market that have not previously been members of health and fitness clubs. Between
February 2015 and February 2023, value clubs accounted for 82% of new fitness club membership
additions in the UK. We believe that value clubs have been able to take market share because they offer
a more affordable, flexible and “value for money” product than other private clubs, and value clubs
address the most significant barriers to UK consumers taking on gym memberships (high membership
fees and fixed-duration membership contracts), appealing to a broad range of consumers.

While the value club segment has grown quickly over the past several years, we believe there remains
significant opportunity for further growth due to value club’s broad consumer appeal. The UK gym
market is large with a £5.3 billion market size in 2022 and growing in terms of gym memberships
between 2015 and 2022. As of 2022, 16% of the UK population have gym memberships, which is below
penetration rates in Denmark of 17% in 2023 and the U.S. of 22% in 2021 (Source:
_Deloitte/EuropeActive Report, OC&C Report). Given the UK has a high average monthly membership_
fee of £40, the UK value club sector has headroom for even further penetration growth.

The recent shift in UK consumer trends towards “value for money” is also prevalent in other industries.
Looking at the supermarket industry, value operators such as Lidl and Aldi have taken market share
from incumbent mid-market operators like WM Morrison and Tesco. Another example is the airline
industry, where value carriers such as EasyJet and Ryanair have taken market share (in terms of number
of passengers) from traditional premium airlines like British Airways. An underlying element of this
trend is the simplicity and consistency of a high-quality, yet affordable offering that aims to perfect the
core product with “no frills.”

**Value club operators in the UK**

We are the largest value club operator in the UK, with 352 clubs and 1.4 million members as of June
30, 2023, and are over 1.5 times larger, by number of clubs and members, than the second value club
operator, The Gym Group (Source: Company information). There can be significant differences in the
product offering of value club operators. For example, PureGym and The Gym Group generally offer

other value clubs, PureGym clubs generally have dedicated group exercise studios, including purpose
built stationary cycling studios and offer a wide variety of instructor-led exercise classes in our studios.

**Overview of the Swiss health and fitness club market**

The Swiss health and fitness club market has grown steadily in recent years. Between February 2015
and February 2019, the number of health and fitness club members in Switzerland grew from an
estimated 0.95 million to an estimated 1.26 million. As of February 2022, the estimated memberships
were 1.16 million and approximately 13.3% of the Swiss population was a member of a health and
fitness club (Source: OC&C Report).

The growth in health and fitness club members from February 2015 to February 2019 reflected
population growth driven by continued net positive immigration and penetration rate growth driven by
increased fitness supply and health consciousness. Post-COVID-19, the Swiss fitness market has
exhibited healthy recovery and has recovered to pre-COVID-19 levels of club membership and number
of clubs. The Swiss health and fitness club market had 1.20 million members as of February 2023
compared to 1.18 million in 2019.

Switzerland has the highest average gym/fitness club membership fees in Europe, due to the high wage
and price level in Switzerland. As of February 2022, the average monthly club fee in Switzerland was
approximately €78 per month, compared to £40 in the UK and €32 in Denmark (Source: OC&C
_Report). The Swiss market is also estimated to have a smaller low-cost segment, at 20% of the total_
member base, than similarly developed European markets, such as in Northern Europe. Compared to
developed European markets, gym penetration in Switzerland has considerable headroom for growth
and is expected to grow.

The top three operators in the Swiss fitness market account for approximately 31% of the total
membership base (Source: Deloitte/EuropeActive Report, OC&C Report). Most health and fitness club
operators in Switzerland offer fixed contracts of 12 months, requesting upfront membership fee
payments. We are the first to offer monthly rolling memberships in Switzerland and are by far the
largest value operator in the country with a three times larger membership base compared to the second
largest value player in the country as of 2022.

**Overview**

We are the second largest gym and fitness operator in Europe by number of gyms, with over 550 sites
and approximately 1.9 million members across our estate. We provide high quality, low cost, flexible
physical fitness facilities and have market leading positions in each of our three key markets: the UK,
Denmark and Switzerland.

Our operating model provides a powerful customer proposition that is differentiated from traditional
gym operators and appeals to a broad range of consumers. The key elements of our model proposition
include affordable membership fees, flexible contracts, a large footprint in each of our key markets and
24/7 access (in most locations) to high-quality gyms. This proposition is underpinned by the
differentiated, capital-efficient and technology-enabled gym operating model, which enables us to
support high levels of membership, operate on low costs and generate strong unit economics, cash flow
conversion and ROCE, and provides us with a strong platform for expansion.

Our strategic mission is to be a leading provider of affordable and flexible fitness memberships to
high-quality fitness facilities in current and new markets. Our customer value proposition, differentiated
business model and well-managed growth strategy has allowed us to grow rapidly in multiple
geographies through new site roll-outs, acquisitions and membership expansion. We are the largest
operator of gyms in the UK both by number of gyms and members. Following our acquisition of the
Fitness World Group in 2020, we also became the leading operator in Denmark by number of gyms and
members and the leading value gym operator in Switzerland by number of gyms and members. In 2021,
we launched a franchise model with the first franchised sites opening in the Middle East, which has
allowed us to bring our affordable, accessible gym proposition to a number of exciting new markets
and provides a platform for expanding our franchised offering to other territories in the future. In 2022,
we also opened our first three corporate-owned gyms in the U.S. with over 11,000 members as of
June 30, 2023.

For the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, we generated revenue of £515.3 million and a Run-Rate
Adjusted EBITDA of £128.4 million, an increase of 14% and 19%, respectively, from the twelve
months ended June 30, 2022.

**_Key Strengths_**

We believe that our key strengths are as follows:

**_Attractive and resilient fitness market driven by the winning value segment gym model_**

The European health and fitness club market had total revenues of €28 billion as of December 2022,
almost reaching the pre-COVID-19 revenues of €28.2 billion as of December 2019 (Source:
_Deloitte/EuropeActive Report), and similarly, fitness club membership volumes are recovering towards,_
and in some markets beyond, pre-COVID-19 levels. Memberships are showing consistent growth across
most European geographies, driven by structural trends towards greater consumer health awareness and
high importance, government support and promotion of fitness, as well as continued increase in gym
capacity. Over the four years from February 2015 to February 2019, gym membership in Europe was

114


-----

estimated to have increased from 54 million to 65 million, which reflects an estimated CAGR of 4.8%
(Source: OC&C Report). In 2022, European memberships increased by approximately 7 million
members, or 12% from 56 million in 2021 to 63 million (Source: Deloitte/EuropeActive Report).

The value gym segment, in which we operate, has continued its long-term growth in both volume and
market share terms, as operators have expanded the market by providing affordable fitness options to
an underserved population. In all our key geographic markets, the value gym segment has continued to
gain share. In Europe, between 2015 and 2022, the share of net gym membership additions by 15 out
of the top 20 value operators was 91%. In all our core markets of the UK, Denmark and Switzerland
the value gym segment has also grown its share of memberships. For example, in the UK (the largest
market in Europe by revenue), between February 2015 and February 2023, value operators accounted
for 82% of net new member additions, meaning value share increased from 20% in 2016 to 28% in
2022, and again to 30% in 2023 (Source: Deloitte/EuropeActive Report, OC&C Report).

We believe the value fitness model will have greater overall success, compared to traditional fitness
models, due to its scalability and because it is economically superior to traditional gym center operating
models. The model generates significantly higher EBITDA due to lower costs (approximately £0.4
million EBITDA for a value gym as compared to approximately £0.3 million EBITDA for a mid-market
gym), lower capital expenditure to fit out each unit (£1.0 to £1.5 million for a value gym as compared
to £1.5 to £2.0 million for a mid-market gym). This delivers higher and more sustainable ROCE
(approximately 35% for a value gym as compared to approximately 18% for a mid-market gym)
(Source: Company information). For more information, see “—Operating model combines strong
_revenue management and low labor cost.”_

The gym market has demonstrated resilience during periods of both economic uncertainty and the
COVID-19 pandemic. The COVID-19 pandemic caused unprecedented disruption to the fitness
industry, causing gyms to close across all markets in Europe and inevitably membership numbers
declined significantly during these periods of disclosure. In spite of this, the market has recovered very
strongly and is now back to pre-pandemic levels. See “Industry Overview—Overview of the gym-based
_fitness market.” Many of the larger operators have emerged stronger following the pandemic, as gym_
operators required strong liquidity positions to be able to withstand the periods of extended closure
during local and nationwide lockdowns. Some weaker operators in both the value and mid-market gym
segments exited their respective markets, thereby increasing available space for expansion and creating
underserved demand. In addition, we believe that even if a weakened competitor did not exit the market,
it will, in general, struggle to maintain product quality because it will lack the resources to reinvest and
will struggle to raise new capital in the now more challenging market for financing.

The gym market has also traded strongly through previous economic downturns. This is well
demonstrated by data through the global financial crisis in 2008 and 2009, evidenced by an estimated
2.1% CAGR in total gym spend in the UK health and fitness club market between 2006 and 2012.
During this time period total gym spend did not fall during any individual year. From 2008 to 2012,
value gyms grew significantly, with membership increasing by an estimated CAGR of 121% (Source:
_OC&C Report)._

As the market figures show, gyms have continued to perform strongly through the recent economic
downturn. For example, in the UK memberships are estimated to have increased from 9.5 million in
February 2022 to 10 million in February 2023, representing an increase of over 5%. Consumer research
shows that consumers prioritize their gym memberships ahead of other areas of discretionary spend
such as eating out, holidays and clothing (Source: OC&C Report).

Against this backdrop, the value sector in the UK has performed particularly well, growing from
approximately 2.7 million memberships to 3.0 million memberships, from February 2022 to
February 2023, which is an increase of 10%. During this period, the value sector has benefitted from
members of premium, mid-market, and public sector gyms trading down, with a net inflow of 219,000
members between 2022 and 2023 alone (Source: OC&C Report).

Furthermore, we believe that the difficult macroeconomic environment seen in 2022 and the first half
of 2023 has provided further challenges for many businesses with pressure from energy costs, general
inflation, interest rates and consumers acting more cautiously. Because strong, well-capitalized players,
such as the Group, will be able to maintain product quality, our relative competitive position will, we
believe, improve over time. This is further evidenced by our cost of living indicators (such as website
traffic, web conversion rate, existing member upgrades, joiner ARPM (as defined below), member
discounting, bad debt recovery, financial concern cancellations and ancillary spend) which have
generally increased or remained consistent year over year in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023.
Additionally, in the twelve months ended June 30, 2023, our UK bad debt collection rate was consistent
with the rate for the twelve months ended June 30, 2019. Despite the impact of COVID-19, concomitant
governmental lockdowns and a challenging macroeconomic environment, we have managed the
business well, having retained our leading market positions, optimized our cost structure, opened 98
sites between January 2020 and June 30, 2023 and continued to increase total member numbers to
1,855,000 as of June 30, 2023. For more on our resilience, see “—Excellent performance management
_and continuous improvement.”_

**_Excellent core product offering delivered across a broad range of site sizes_**

Our core product offering includes the following features:

- _High-quality facilities and inclusive philosophy—we aim to “offer a boutique fitness experience at_
a value gym price.” Our gyms are equipped with a large number of pieces of high-specification
gym equipment, including a broad selection of cardio machines, fixed resistance machines, free
weights and functional and other exercise equipment, such as TRX bands and kettlebells. Our gyms
are clean, well-maintained and are fitted out with high-quality changing rooms and shower
facilities. We offer a welcoming environment and support all members in the pursuit of their fitness
goals, regardless of their current abilities. This is demonstrated, for example, by our “everybody
welcome” philosophy;

- _Superior convenience and proximity to customers as a result of well-developed club network—we_
have the largest and most extensive gym network in the UK and Denmark, with over 50% more
sites in the UK than our closest competitor. This allows us to capitalize on potential members’
desire for proximity. We believe this to be a competitive advantage, given that research indicates
that proximity is among the top two most important factors for members when choosing a gym. In
Denmark we enjoy an even larger market share position and both scale and network advantage
than in the UK when compared to other operators;

- _Group exercise classes—we have dedicated group exercise studios, including purpose-built_
stationary cycling studios in many locations. Most of our gyms offer a wide variety of over 50
classes per week, taught by fitness professionals. Other operators in the value market do not
typically offer such an extensive range of group exercise classes;

- _Membership and access options—we offer flexibility through our range of enrollment offers,_
extended opening hours, premium or off-peak membership options and online membership
management; and

- _Highly effective utilization of space—unlike many mid-market and premium operators, we do not_
install pools, spas, saunas, steam room, extensive cafes or other high-end amenities in our gyms.
These amenities are generally expensive to construct, operate and maintain and take up a
significant amount of leased space. We believe that these amenities are generally less utilized by
members and that by eliminating them we are able to install more pieces of high utilization fitness
equipment, such as treadmills, free weights and stationary bikes. As a result, our gyms can support
high levels of membership while operating on low operating and initial capital investment costs.

116


-----

Our core product offering is hard to replicate at scale, due to our strong presence and member loyalty
in our key markets, and underpins our market leading positions as the number one value gym operator
in the UK, Denmark and Switzerland and number two gym operator in Europe.

**_Great consumer value proposition_**

We have a compelling consumer value proposition. Key elements of this proposition include:

- _Flexible membership—members can sign up with flexible contracts. Accordingly, members have_
the freedom and the flexibility to leave at their convenience without incurring cancellation fees
and have the ability to freeze their memberships for months at a time;

- _Easy to join and online membership management—our online website and app platforms allow_
members to join in just two minutes, manage their memberships, freeze or cancel their
membership, book classes, locate gym facilities, track fitness data and engage in fitness challenges.
This ability to self-serve is convenient for members and lowers costs for the business;

- _Digital integration—we blend high-tech with high performance, including digital studios,_
interactive screens, a coherent online offer and content for workouts and exercise at home when
not in the gym, all of which are available via the PureGym app;

- _Affordable pricing—our flexible and low-cost membership structure provides excellent value for_
money for our members, with student discounts, day passes and off-peak membership options
available in many locations. These options further minimize costs for our members, often enabling
access to affordable fitness where there previously was none. Our variable pricing model, tailored
to the local market, is crucial to maximizing performance and allows us to tailor the offer to each
individual location;

- _Multi-gym access—members can buy an option to access any of our gyms in each country, many_
of which are open 24/7; and

- _Quality equipment and classes—we offer quality gyms, with members able to access_
approximately 50 face-to-face classes per week in many gyms, combined with nutrition, equipment
and personal training options.

Members receive all the above for a price significantly lower than in typical mid-market and premium
gyms. Our average monthly revenue per member was £24.55 as at June 30, 2023 and £24.61 for the six
months ended June 30, 2023, with mid-market and premium gyms typically charging significantly
more.

**_Operating model combines strong revenue management and low labor cost_**

We believe that the value fitness model is economically superior to traditional gym and fitness center
operating models through a combination of low fit-out capex, low equipment and maintenance spending
and high membership density. We believe that the resulting average return on invested capital, per site,
in value gyms is approximately double compared to a typical mid-market operators. As a result, those
operators who successfully deploy the value business model (such as the Group and our international
peers, Basic-Fit, SmartFit and Planet Fitness), benefit from attractive unit margins, rapid paybacks on
initial investment and high ROCE. Therefore, they are able to quickly redeploy capital to support further
network growth, further enhancing scale and associated economies. Our operating model benefits from
the following features:

- _Low personnel costs—we are able to operate our gyms with low levels of employed personnel_

**Strategy**

Our strategy is to further expand our position as a market-leading value gym operator by providing
affordable, flexible and value-for-money memberships in high-quality gyms to anyone who wants to

122


-----

increase their level of fitness, while simultaneously delivering profitable growth. The key elements of
our strategy include:

**_Exploit structural growth opportunity in value gym sector_**

We plan to take advantage of both the opportunity to drive significantly increased penetration of gym
usage and the market shift from mid-market and premium gyms to value gyms. For more on how value
gyms are disrupting the market and taking market share, see “—Key Strengths—Attractive and resilient
_fitness market driven by the winning value segment gym model.” We plan to leverage our experience to_
continue the organic roll-out of new gyms with strong ROCE. Future growth in the value segment will
be driven by the development of new value gyms, continued market share gains from mid-market and
premium operators, as well as public gyms operated by local authorities, and overall growth in gym
participation rates due in part to the increasing awareness and availability of value gyms in each of our
markets. The significant opportunity for further growth in the value gym market is evidenced by:

- the significant success of the value gym concept to date and its broad consumer appeal;

- the current overall penetration rates of gym membership in existing markets; only 14.8% of the
British population as of February 2023, an estimated 16.8% of Danish population as of December
31, 2023, and 13.2% of the Swiss population as of February 2022 (Source: OC&C Report); and

- evidence that penetration can reach or exceed 20% in more mature markets, such as in the US,
Sweden and Norway (Source: OC&C Report).

We believe that we are ideally positioned to capitalize on this substantial market penetration opportunity
as market leader in the United Kingdom, Denmark and Switzerland with a long, successful track record
of opening new gyms and rapidly growing membership, revenue and profitability. As more sites are
rolled out, gym penetration is projected to reach 17% in the United Kingdom by February 2028 (Source:
_OC&C Report)._

Furthermore, smaller, less well-capitalized value operators will, we believe, seek to exit sites rather than
reinvest or recommit to leases when facing competition. In continental Europe, growth will also come
from improvements to our existing sites, such as by reducing costs through operational efficiencies,
reequipping and reinvesting in our core sites and reconfiguring and consolidating our estate, rather than
solely from new site roll-out.

Finally, we seek to establish ourselves as the clear number one gym operator and maintain our position
as the leading value fitness operator in each of our core markets. In the UK and Denmark, we are by a
considerable distance the largest operator by volume of sites and membership. Furthermore, in the UK
we are the largest fitness brand with un-paralleled levels of consumer awareness and consideration.

**_Continue to lead in technology, innovation and operational excellence_**

including:

platform. The “front end” consists of both websites and mobile applications, where our members
can book classes, pay for their memberships and other ancillary services. The “back end” includes
all the investments made to continue to develop leading edge revenue and product management as

which in turn supports our operational performance. This allows our management to better control

  - We believe that an “omni-channel” approach to fitness is increasingly expected by consumers,
and therefore we plan to continue to invest in our digital and connected offering and will
further deploy our own and third-party resources to develop software and content to deliver

  - Our approach seeks to serve a broad range of consumer needs by creating digital enablement
for members to get more out of their workout, whether at home or in the gym. This ranges
from simple digital workout classes for beginners to more sophisticated training programs

- _Driving Average Revenue Per Member— we take a multi-layered approach to increasing ARPM_

pricing for our membership products based on local market demand and dynamics for each
site. Our operational experts tailor pricing to specific local markets and monitor and change
the specific prices over time as the market and its competition evolve. In turn, this allows us
to monitor member enrollment, manage capacity and maximize revenue and returns. For

fitness market responds well to promotional activity, but it is crucial that this is managed
efficiently as otherwise excess value leakage takes place. We use our increasingly
sophisticated technology platform to target promotional investment at the right time for the
right duration, in the right places and using the right mechanics. We measure the true
efficiency and effectiveness of investments carefully so that plans can be optimized.

  - _Increasing ancillary sales per visit—ancillary sales are part of our initiative to increase_
ARPM. For example, we offer sports and energy drinks and protein snacks for purchase
through on-site vending machines.

where this is possible and viable. Capacity optimization can involve the physical extension of
gyms, or the redesign of certain aspects of gyms to eliminate site-specific utilization
bottlenecks, such as the substitution of low utilization equipment, or the installation of
additional automated entry portals or access gates to increase capacity.

**_Sustainability and ESG are key priorities for us_**

Sustainability—and more broadly environmental, social and governance (“S-ESG”)-related issues—is
an important area of focus for us as concerns with climate change increase, consumers and employees
become increasingly engaged with this topic and the obligations being placed on businesses become
clearer on making progress on S-ESG issues to the satisfaction of both regulators and capital providers.

First, and foremost, we believe our business exists to provide a social good, as our core purpose—to
provide accessible, flexible and affordable fitness and activity to all—plays a vital role in not only
improving people’s health and wellbeing, but also as a route to addressing obesity, helping to prevent
illness and improving mental health. Additionally, our business is inherently sustainable as gyms are
effectively a part of the “sharing economy” and, especially in the case of low cost/high volume gyms
like ours, are a good, sustainable use of resources. Because members effectively “rent” access to the
gym facilities and equipment for the hours that they need, the equipment utilization is high and is an
efficient use of resources rather than further mass production of relevant equipment for each individual.

Notwithstanding this positive starting position, we recognize there is increased consumer awareness of
the link between societal trends and sustainability-related issues, and there is some evidence that these
trends are driving consumer demand towards companies that chose to pay more attention—and more
authentic attention—to issues in the S-ESG arena. Therefore, we believe it also makes good business
sense to be proactive in addressing S-ESG issues, as well as there being support for this from many
investors and a growing sense of the moral obligation on leading companies to play an appropriate role
in this regard.

Following engagement with key stakeholders—employees, members, investors and third-party
partners—we have identified five key focus areas in which to develop our S-ESG strategy:

- _Delivering Social Good—supporting as many people as possible to live healthier lives;_

- _Empowering People—fostering a thriving healthy team and community where everyone feels_
welcome and supported to reach their potential;

- _Energy and Emissions—reducing our carbon footprint and efficient use of resources;_

- _Waste & Circulatory—minimizing operational waste and embedding circular-by-design principles_
across our operations; and

- _Effective Corporate Governance—building an environment of trust, transparency and_
accountability for sustainable performance.

In 2022, we fast-tracked our decarbonization plans due to the emergence of the energy crisis, primarily
resulting from the Russia-Ukraine conflict which commenced in February of 2022. We have been
working with a market leading operational improvement consultant to identify and pursue opportunities
to significantly reduce energy usage per site. In doing so, we are in the process of establishing a new
“green” standard by which our operations are run, including new gym environment and temperature set
points; upgrades to LED lighting specification; control systems for better management of heating,
ventilation and air conditioning and, in some cases and where feasible, on-site renewable power
generation. A structured implementation program is underway with the objective of delivering
improved energy performance and broader environmental impact across our estate throughout 2023.
We are also continuing to develop measures of performance, targets and specific objectives for each of
the other emerging themes.

Our sustainability strategy approach to climate related risks and transition action plans are overseen by
the Risk and Sustainability Action Team (“RSAT”), which is chaired by our CEO and consists of our
Director of Strategic Sustainability and five other senior managers and executives. This committee
meets on at least a quarterly basis and oversees a prioritized program of work to address our key issues.

127


-----

The RSAT is further supported by external specialist advisers from time to time to ensure we are subject
to appropriate objective external challenges and contributions.

The RSAT reports, in writing, to the Board on a regular basis and the Board conducts an annual review
of our S-ESG strategy, progress and performance. In order to monitor our S-ESG strategy, the RSAT
prepared a climate risk register, which is regularly reviewed, and is developing S-ESG key performance
indicators. For additional details on our sustainability initiatives, see “—Sustainability, Environment,
_Social and Governance (S-ESG).”_

**History**

The Company was established in September 2008 by entrepreneur Peter Roberts, who recognized that
there was a significant opportunity in the UK health and fitness market for a value gym offering. Peter
launched PureGym to disrupt the market by providing high quality exercise facilities to a broad
consumer base at affordable prices and on flexible contract terms.

In November 2009, the first two PureGyms were opened in Manchester and Leeds, with a third gym
opened in Edinburgh in December 2009. We built upon the success of our first three gyms and opened
six new gyms in 2010. Since 2010, we have increased the pace of roll-out of new gyms, growing from

Our gyms are located in towns, cities and other populous areas, and we have a balanced portfolio of
gyms throughout our European markets, including a strong presence in the London area, Copenhagen
and Zurich. Our model has proven successful in a wide variety of property types, such as former retail
park warehouses, grocery stores, offices, car showrooms, basements, factories and nightclubs and
demographic catchments, which we believe indicates that there are a significant number of site
alternatives that can be selected for future gyms.

We have opened, and intend to continue opening, new gyms in certain areas where we already operate
a gym (or gyms) and where we believe there is sufficient demand for additional gyms. We believe that
this strengthens our membership proposition over our competitors by providing members with the
flexibility and convenience to use multiple gyms (e.g., near both home and work) and strengthening the
local brand.

**Gym format and size**

Our gyms generally have the following key characteristics and components:

- 24 hours a day, seven days a week, 365 days a year gym access, which allows our members to
adapt their use of the gym to fit their individual lifestyles;

- a large number and wide range of high quality, award-winning gym equipment from leading
manufacturers, including Matrix, Precor, BLK Box and Technogym;

- one or two dedicated studio fitness areas, including in many cases dedicated stationary cycling
studios, which enable each gym to offer approximately 50 face-to-face classes per week;

- sports water dispensing machines and vending machines;

- self-cleaning and hand-sanitizing stations;

- clean and well-appointed shower and changing facilities as well as disabled access, disabled toilets
and shower facilities;

- two to four fully-automated PIN and RFID tag- or QR code-controlled entry portals, speed gates
or turnstiles for secure member access;

- free Wi-Fi internet access complemented by 4/5G where available and a professional sound
system;

- continuously recording CCTV security cameras, proactively managed and monitored by our
in-house team during non-peak hours; and

- at least one member of staff, a fitness professional or a member of the cleaning team, who is trained
in first aid, present for the majority of the hours of operation as well as CCTV monitoring when
gym sites are unmanned.

We tailor our gym format to local market conditions to offer the best possible member experience. As
a result, in addition to the common features described above, certain gyms may have specific features,

130


-----

such as “ladies only” areas or a bigger focus on plate loaded, free weights and fixed pin areas with
smaller cardio and functional areas or vice versa. Our gyms do not have cafes, saunas, steam rooms,
spas or pools, which are typically used by a small percentage of gym members. These amenities result
in higher operating and Initial Capital Investment costs, while lowering the amount of high-utilization
gym floor space, which limits the number of members gyms can support.

Our gyms vary in size since our operational model is highly adaptable to both large and small spaces,
which allows us to serve members across a broad range of catchments. Our small box format gyms are
typically in the range of 6,000 to 9,000 square feet and generally have 1,800 to 2,200 members with a
typical market catchment of 10,000 to 25,000 (as compared to 10,000 to 12,000 square feet and 12,000
to 22,000 square feet, 2,800 to 3,400 members and 4,000 to 6,000 members and catchments of 15,000
to 35,000 and 30,000 plus, for medium box and large box format gyms respectively, in each case). The
small box format gyms enable us to grow into areas that would not otherwise support a larger sized
gym.

**Fitness equipment**

Our gyms are equipped with a broad range of high-quality fitness equipment primarily consisting of
cardiovascular and resistance equipment such as treadmills, climb mills, cross trainers, stationary bikes
and fixed resistance weight machines. In addition, our gyms are equipped with an extensive free weights
section, as well as other specialized training equipment such as functional rigs, kettlebells, TRX bands,
battle ropes, medicine balls and foam rollers. The majority of our gyms also have stationary exercise
bikes for cycling classes, as well as functional training zones, which targets an area of fitness that has
significantly grown in popularity recently. We monitor the latest exercise and fitness trends as well as
consumer dynamics in our gyms in order to make a decision regarding changes to our gym equipment.
For example, in gyms where we seek to attract a younger demographic, we have added in an expanded
free weights area and tailored group classes. Data analysis is also used for optimization of a specific
piece of equipment to its designated zone.

We only select equipment we believe to be high quality and designed for heavy and frequent use. A
majority of our cardiovascular and resistance equipment is supplied by either Matrix, Precor or
Technogym, depending on the gym location, whilst our free weights and functional accessories are
supplied by BLK Box or Jordan Fitness. Our M&A Conversion gyms are also equipped with other
third-party suppliers. We believe that purchasing high quality equipment results in an improved member
experience, reduces maintenance expenditure and ensures a longer equipment lifecycle.

The specific fitness equipment installed in each gym is designed for each space based on management’s
view of expected utilization allowing for geographic, demographic and other factors. Gym equipment
is generally installed in phases. At opening, a base level of equipment is installed in each gym. This
base level can then be increased if membership begins to substantially increase above expectation and
actual usage patterns are observed and analyzed. This is part of our capital efficient fit-out strategy and
ensures that we are able to tailor our product offering at the local level.

We are focused on maintaining the high quality of our gym equipment in order to provide our members
with a compelling in-gym experience. As such, we have comprehensive fitness equipment and
maintenance programs with our suppliers who are contracted to repair any non-functioning piece of
equipment within specified timeframes, as well as employees who are able to serve as technicians in
certain locations. We have a six to ten year replacement cycle for most equipment items over which
time the equipment is depreciated on a straight-line basis. See “Management’s Discussion and Analysis
_of Financial Condition and Results of Operations.”_

**Other fitness services**

Our gyms aim to offer a varied product offering, including at our small box format gyms. For example,
the majority of our gyms offer the opportunity for members to buy personal training sessions delivered
by professionally qualified fitness professionals. We aim to attract fitness professionals who are
