-----

passionate about fitness and who specialize in specific areas such as sports therapy, injury rehabilitation,
nutrition and strength and conditioning. Additionally, our gyms typically have one or two dedicated
group exercise studios per gym, including cycling studios fitted out with purpose built stationary bikes.
Each gym generally offers approximately 50 face-to-face classes per week taught by qualified fitness
professionals. In some gyms, video/virtual classes are also offered in the gym and are accessible at any
time for members of those gyms. Members are able to book places in studio classes seven to fourteen
days in advance using the PureGym mobile app, our website or in-gym kiosks.

We believe that dedicated studio areas and a large fitness class offering attract a broader demographic
of members, enhance member satisfaction and offer greater utilization of space during peak times. Most
of our gyms also offer a varying range of services as bolt-on membership options, such as priority class
booking, access to a digital body composition tracker and sports water. In addition, our members have
access to workouts, nutritional advice, progress tracking and training plans through the PureGym app.
Our apps provide all members with numerous virtual classes available for free download for use ingym or at home. We believe these additional fitness services differentiate us from many of our
competitors in the value gym market.

**Members**

**_Overview_**

We are the largest operator of gyms in the UK by number of sites and members and the second largest
gym and fitness operator in Europe by number of sites, with approximately 1,855,000 members as of
June 30, 2023 across our estate. Our customer value proposition is based on providing members with
affordable, flexible and value for money access to a national network of high-quality and
well-maintained gyms. As a result of our affordable price point, strong value for money offer and
“everybody welcome” philosophy and marketing message, we attract a broad range of consumers, from
a wide variety of demographic and socio-economic backgrounds. many of whom have not been
members of a gym previously due to high prices or the lack of flexibility and value in the offering. We
also attract many members from traditional health club operators because of our compelling product
offer and lower price points. We believe these factors will continue to resonate even more with
consumers in a post-COVID-19 world with more flexible working and lifestyle patterns.

**_Membership Tenure_**

Our business model resonates strongly with members and has resulted in member loyalty and a growing
average member tenure. For example, Average Continuous Membership Tenure in the UK for the 269
clubs open on January 1, 2021 was 16.5 months as of June 30, 2023, which is longer than a typical
one-year gym contract. Average tenure has been increasing over time, up from 15 months as of
June 2022 to 16.5 months in June 2023 as illustrated in the following chart:

Many members who terminate their memberships later return. Of our UK members that left in 2019
and 2020, 39% later re-joined. We believe our members have a lower than average likelihood of

long, continuous membership tenure and retention of former members is a testament to our strong

Our high level of monthly member value retention, which was between 90% and 95% between

throughout a member’s lifetime, proactive revenue management and high retention rates among our

**_Membership Offerings_**

Key to our proposition is the simple and transparent “no contract” flexible membership. In our model,
most members are not bound to any fixed term contract or commitment and simply pay on a monthly
basis in advance for their membership, almost entirely by direct debit (first payments are typically made
by card). Members have the ability to freeze or leave at any time, which provides flexibility that appeals
to a broad cross-section of potential members in the market.

The “Core” membership product provides unlimited access to a member’s chosen gym. In addition to
this “Core” membership, we offer a number of additional membership options. We offer discounted
“Off Peak” memberships in many gyms, where access is restricted to quieter times (such as on weekends
and/or in the middle of the day) so pricing is lower. In addition, members can choose to pay a higher
fee and select premium membership options such as “Multi,” “Plus” or “Premium” which provide
additional benefits, such as being able to access more than one gym, bringing a guest along to work out
with, priority class bookings or entitlement to additional services, such as sports water, nutritional
products, body composition monitoring and/or massage beds in some gyms. These options provide
members with a range of flexibility to tailor their membership to best suit their personal needs. This
also assists us in optimizing revenue across gyms to leverage our nationwide footprint and optimize
value-added sales since, for example, each Plus membership sold in the UK earns us an extra £5 to £10
per month. As of June 30, 2023, in the UK, 58% of members held “Core” memberships, 9% held “Off
Peak” memberships, 29% held premium options and 4% held other products such as student
memberships.

In addition to rolling monthly memberships, we sell fixed term memberships (for example 12 months),
paid upfront. These are popular with certain member segments like students and are popular in
Switzerland because they are the way that people are used to paying for gym membership. We also sell
shorter term “day passes” which can be bought (at a slightly higher price) to access facilities for specific
one, three, seven, or 30 days at a time. This is a useful “trial” option for prospects or a good option for
people who travel regularly. These short-term “day pass” options do not form part of the membership
count.

**_Membership pricing_**

We have invested significant resources in revenue management and operate a dynamic pricing strategy
across our estate with pricing set at gym specific level, reflecting the variability of local catchments.
This is a key strategic differentiator to many other value gym operators. Gym pricing is transparent on
our website and mobile apps and is a core component of our affordable value proposition, which also
differentiates us from traditional mid-market and premium health and fitness operators.

Pricing is managed centrally and is reviewed frequently by senior management, incorporating a
sophisticated range of data alongside feedback from local and regional management. The goal of this
dynamic variable pricing is to optimize revenue and consequently site profitability through the effective
balancing of yield, volume and capacity in order to ensure member experience is also optimized.
Internal and external factors are considered in pricing decisions to ensure site potential is realized from
inception through to maturity.

**_Member engagement and satisfaction_**

We believe that regular, relevant engagement with members results in a better customer experience and
inspires members to use the gym more frequently and achieve their fitness goals. Higher satisfaction

134


-----

and more active gym usage in turn typically increases membership duration and leads to
recommendations to family, friends, and relatives. We seek to engage with our current members in a
number of ways. On a personal level, gym managers and fitness professionals are encouraged to develop
relationships with members and support the achievement of their fitness goals. We also use technology
to engage with customers and educate them about fitness. See “—Technology.” We also seek to engage
with former members and encourage them to return to our gyms through email or in-app messaging.

Achieving high levels of customer satisfaction is our key objective and management tracks satisfaction
levels closely. We gather feedback from members largely through regular estate-wide, Net Promoter
Score monitoring at club level alongside additional feedback mechanisms. We use the results in all
levels of decision-making, including operations, product design, pricing, site fit-out and maintenance.
Customer feedback scores are also used as a component of the incentive and bonus awards for gym
managers and senior gym employees.

**Access**

The majority of our gyms in the UK are accessible by members seven days a week, 365 days a year and
24/7 opening is due to be expanded across much of the estate in Switzerland as well. In Denmark,
opening hours are typically 5:00 AM or 6:00 AM to midnight and this is considered to be optimal for
that market. Entry and exit are controlled via automated and computer-controlled entry portals, speed
gates or turnstiles and members have their own unique PIN-codes and/or RFID bands or key fobs,
tokens or membership cards, which grant them access. Fraud prevention measures are in place to limit
the risk of multiple individuals using the same membership or PIN number. The automated entry
systems track and provide data on usage patterns so that gym managers can actively manage capacity
and monitor key performance indicators. See “—Other fitness services.”

We believe that we have developed a rigorous, transparent and professional approach to identifying
new sites and to guiding decision-making over capital investment. We also believe that the discipline
of our property acquisition process, combined with the institutional knowledge gained from opening
more gyms than any other private, low-cost gym operator in the UK since 2009 and any other gym
operator in Denmark since 2005, is a major contributor to our significant growth, competitive advantage
and success. In addition, we believe the power of our UK property acquisition team and process is
evidenced by the fact that our UK Mature Gyms delivered an Average Gym ROCE of 35% in the twelve
months ended June 30, 2023.

Our overall strategic objective is to secure and develop gyms at properties that are well located,
contribute to positive “cluster effects” and deliver attractive and sustainable returns on invested capital.
A structured and disciplined approach has been crucial for successful site acquisition and has helped us
build a strong nationwide site portfolio. We have a four-stage new site acquisition process, which
includes: (1) Initial Site Targeting; (2) Preliminary Screening of Opportunities; (3) Detailed Evaluation
and Assessment of Priorities; and (4) Formal Feasibility Reports and Investment Decision Making (as
described below). Our rigorous approach to site selection, which includes approval of all new sites by
the Group Capex Committee (including the CEO and CFO) and requires a ROCE feasibility target of
over 30%, is designed to ensure a high-quality pipeline across all geographies. Although the process
sometimes varies by geography, our intention is to standardize the process across all jurisdictions over
time. We lease all of our gym sites.

**_The Property Acquisition Team_**

We have dedicated property acquisition teams that are responsible for identifying potential targets and
consistently tracking local competitor new site openings. The property acquisition teams leverage their
extensive property experience, their credibility with landlords and their strong relationships with local
real-estate agents to negotiate the best possible rental deals, as well as having strong relationships with
landlords, developers, agents and other gym operators and retailers who may be looking to divest sites.
The property acquisition teams use multiple site identification methods to identify potential targets and
establish potential hurdles for each location, with a focus on membership potential at each site. The
teams are also responsible for detailed site criteria and specifications. For example, in the UK, over
1,000 core locations are being tracked and assessed, approximately 400 locations are under active
analysis and investigation and approximately 100 are in negotiation.

**_Initial Site Targeting_**

The responsibilities of our property acquisition teams include identifying potential site locations,
evaluating their suitability, developing financial forecasts for prospective sites in conjunction with the
operations, finance and development teams and negotiating lease terms with landlords. The property
acquisition teams use extensive data and proprietary tools to identify and evaluate new gym sites. We
use a number of approaches to ensure we are identifying a large number and broad cross section of
potential new locations for our gyms, such as working with external consultants to build a proprietary
postcode driven assessment model to help it identify potentially attractive locations using demographic,
socio-economic and other data.

136


-----

**_Preliminary Screening of Opportunities_**

Given the number of locations and opportunities that we identify, we have developed a disciplined and
efficient approach to screening opportunities focusing on six key evaluation parameters, including site
characteristics, headline population and demographic characteristics, likely lease terms, location
characteristics, local competitive dynamics and other important local considerations.

**_Detailed Evaluation and Assessment of Priorities_**

After the initial screening phase, we perform more detailed evaluations of potential sites, including
steps such as creating financial forecasts and returns models and performing an analysis of potential
impact on existing sites if relevant.

**_Formal Feasibility Report and Investment Decision-Making_**

If a site is deemed to be attractive following the detailed evaluation, a formal feasibility report is
prepared. The work and documentation for these reports is standardized and they are prepared by the
property acquisition team. If the Group Capex Committee approves a formal feasibility report, the lease
for the site will be entered into, unless the circumstances change in the intervening period.

**_Site Development_**

Once a lease for a new site has been entered into, our development teams take responsibility for
managing the construction of the gym. We have robust processes, a proprietary data set of benchmark
costs, and very strong contractor and supplier relationships to assist in the development of sites. These
factors continue to be a major contributor to our strong growth, competitive advantage and success.

**_Gym opening targets and pipeline_**

We believe that we have a substantial advantage over competitors for acquiring leased space given our
strong brand, leading market positions, historically strong landlord covenant, excellent reputation and
proven ability to drive footfall to landlords’ properties. We believe that there is a market opportunity to
double the size of our business in the medium term, largely in our existing operating countries. This
would provide approximately 800 to 1,100 gyms.

**_Property leases_**

We seek to enter economically feasible leases with sufficient length of term to justify the development
costs of gyms. In addition, we also seek to ensure that our leases protect us from substantial increases
in rents due to potential future volatility in the commercial property market and provide it with sufficient
flexibility to exit unprofitable locations. Our organic site lease agreements typically include our
standard key terms, which provide us with substantial visibility over our future property costs, such as
10-to-15-year terms, tenant-only break rights at year ten and limits on rent increase parameters.

**Franchise Model**

In 2021, we launched our franchise model. The aim of this model is for us to take our affordable,
accessible gym proposition to markets with limited current access to such facilities and provides an
exciting platform to expand the business’ reach to other territories. Our franchise model allows us to
develop our estate network across other areas of the world, through leveraging our core intellectual
property and optimized operating model, as well as create value through low-capital-intensive EBITDA
growth. Through our franchise model, we aim to partner with credible, expert local partners who have
access to capital and the resources to build a leading market position, are well connected with landlords
and are experienced in real estate, have a business presence in the region and have a strong cultural and
legislative knowledge of the region.

Through our franchise model, we offer franchise partners the opportunity to gain access to our worldclass brand and operating model, including through leveraging our tech-enabled operations such as our

137


-----

website, apps and member management system, our operational experts, our in-house real estate experts
and our marketing team. In turn, we are able to redeploy franchise revenue into our corporate-owned
sites. In addition to our operating model being attractive to members, our operating model is attractive
for franchisee operators because our proven format is adaptable to a wide range of site sizes, property
markets and population concentrations, is digitally enabled (allowing for a low cost per acquisition) and
has been shown to work with low personnel costs.

We intend to selectively expand the number of franchised sites in existing franchise markets as well as
entering new markets, in order to increase revenues and broaden our reach with limited capital
requirement. We believe there are a number of markets, particularly the United States, as well as South
Korea, Japan, South East Asia and ASEAN and India, where we could be successful based on our
understanding of the local competitive landscape and the potential for a branded low-cost, high value
gym operator in these markets. We believe that current and prospective franchise partners can launch
approximately 400 franchised sites by 2028 throughout the globe.

In 2022, we entered into a regional development agreement with the Al Hokair Group to develop a
minimum of 130 sites across the Middle East. As of June 30, 2023, we had 16 franchised sites currently
in operation in Saudi Arabia and the UAE, excluding sites in presale. We believe that in the fullness of
time the Middle Eastern franchise opportunity could be up to 300 sites.

In 2022, we opened our first three gyms in the United States and under the brand PureFitness, which
are corporate owned, with the aim of testing our low-cost, technology-enabled concept in a new
international territory. Having successfully tested our three corporate-owned gyms, we are now seeking
five to ten operating partners, with potential for at least 100 sites, as franchisees in the U.S. over the
next five years who will expand our footprint across the US.

**Seasonality**

We experience a small degree of seasonality. The key months for membership growth are
January/February and August/September/October. Seasonality is generally positively driven by
consumers’ desire to improve their fitness at the start of the year and the start of new university/school
terms and negatively impacted by Christmas and summer holidays. Marketing spend is generally
increased during peak joining periods, particularly the January/February period.

**Marketing**

Our “everybody welcome” philosophy and marketing message positions us as an affordable provider
of high-quality health and fitness facilities that welcome all people regardless of their current levels of

**Technology**

Technology is a critical component of our business model. We use technology to enhance our customer
value proposition and augment the membership experience, while simultaneously using it to drive

139


-----

operating and capital cost efficiencies and enable the senior management team to better manage the
business.

For members, technology enables convenient and easy online joining and membership management as
well as 24-hours-a-day (where available), seven-days-a-week, 365-days-a-year access to many of our
gyms. Customers can sign up for memberships via our websites and PureGym mobile apps. Members
can also use our websites and mobile apps to book places in exercise classes, manage their membership
status and follow workout plans.

In addition to enhancing the proposition, our technology infrastructure enables us to lower operating
costs and more efficiently run our business. For example, we use an online member management system
provided and hosted by eXerp to process new memberships, update member information and store
member data. The eXerp system interfaces with the Gantner gym access system, which controls gym
access for members via PIN, RFID wristband, key fob and QR code scanning via the mobile app. These
systems allow all of our gyms to operate without a staffed reception, with our Swiss gyms to be fully
integrated into the eXerp system by the end of 2023. Our online joining process also allows us to operate
without an expensive in-gym sales force. In addition to joining, many aspects of a customer’s
membership can be managed by members online or via the PureGym mobile apps such planning a visit
based on gym capacity, as booking places in classes or upgrading, tracking gym activities, transferring
and freezing memberships. We believe our online membership management services are highly
differentiated in the global health and fitness market.

Technology is also used to reduce fit out and maintenance costs. For example, equipment heat maps are
developed in partnership with suppliers and used to configure newly opened gyms to reduce wear and
tear on equipment and provide equipment utilization reports. We have also developed and use a
proprietary capacity management tool, which allows it to track and monitor the capacity of gyms and
identify bottlenecks at different stages of the member journey. Eliminating these bottlenecks allows
gyms to support higher levels of membership.

We have invested substantially in our internal IT capabilities and have brought a number of core IT
functions in-house. Our IT team is led by our Group Chief Information Officer with a team of 85
permanent full-time employees. The role of the IT team is to drive value out of current and future
technology investments and work alongside the other business areas to explore new opportunities and
support growth. We believe that direct ownership of, and control over, our core technology interface
with members and business partners is a source of competitive advantage for the company.

Individual gyms have IT infrastructures to provide local access network service, provide free Wi-Fi to
members (in most facilities) and ensure back-up PIN and access data for the site. All gyms in the UK
(and an increasing number across Denmark and Switzerland) are equipped with continuously recording
closed-circuit television security cameras. These are proactively monitored outside of normal staffing
hours by an in-house team and video is recorded at each access control point for fraud detection and
prevention.

Our back-office computer systems are comprised of a variety of technologies designed to assist in the
management and analysis of our revenue, costs and key operational metrics as well as support the daily
operations of our office-based and remotely located staff. These include an in-house developed business
intelligence system and a third-party hosted financial system.

Our information technology strategy is aligned to support our business strategy and operating plans.
We maintain an ongoing comprehensive program to replace or upgrade key systems, enhance security
and optimize performance. We believe that our IT systems are scalable and can support our growth
plans.

**Sustainability, Environment, Social and Governance (S-ESG)**

In 2021, we recognized the need to formalize our approach to sustainability and embed sustainability
into our core mission and business model. In taking strides to become an industry leader in sustainability
we appointed a Director of Strategic Sustainability to help facilitate the design and implementation of
our sustainability system including strategy development, goal setting, action planning, and highquality reporting and disclosures in accordance with global standards.

We completed a materiality assessment to identify and evaluate the ESG issues which were most
material to our business and assessed these against the likely impact that those areas had on the business
and our strategic direction. In consultation with our four main stakeholder groups: employees, investors,
supply chain partners and members, we identified the following focus areas to develop our S-ESG
Strategy:

- _Delivering Social Good—supporting as many people as possible to live healthier lives;_

- _Empowering People—fostering a thriving healthy team and community where everyone feels_
welcome and supported to reach their potential;

- _Energy and Emissions—reducing our carbon footprint and efficient use of resources;_

- _Waste & Circulatory—minimizing operational waste and embedding circular-by-design principles_
across our operations; and

- _Effective Corporate Governance—building an environment of trust, transparency and_
accountability for sustainable performance.

We are committed to ensuring our S-ESG agenda is aligned with the United Nations Sustainable
Development Goals (“UN SDGs”) so as to create meaningful links to broader global sustainably-driven
outcomes including specific measures of performance, targets and objectives. Furthermore, we believe
we are compliant or on a path to compliance with the principles arising from Regulation (EU)
2019/2088, the Sustainable Finance Disclosures Regulation.

We are a purpose-led business deeply rooted in our mission to provide a meaningful and valued service
to society and to help people make a positive difference to their lives through being more physically
active: by its nature, our business furthers the social good of helping people improve their physical and
mental health. By virtue of the low-price, no-contract and flexible business model, we believe have
opened up the opportunity for physical activity to many hundreds of thousands of people who would
otherwise have been excluded from such activity. The WHO is unequivocal in its support for the view
that even modest levels of activity are important to preserve the health of people of all ages. We
therefore believe that the considerable investments we have made over time have made a significant
positive difference to the physical and mental health of hundreds of thousands, if not millions of people.

In 2022, we became the official gym partner of The British Heart Foundation (the “BHF”). We are
committed to supporting the BHF in raising awareness of heart and circularity diseases, and how to
prevent them, as well as raising £3.0 million over the next three years to fund important research
projects. In December 2022, we were named BHF Corporate Partner of the Year.

Highlights from the first years of our partnership included:

- raising nearly £1 million for critical science-based research projects;

- supporting the development of the ‘Healthy Hearts Programme’ providing free access to
educational and practical tools to enable everybody to take control of their heart health;

- delivering CPR training through Group RevivR sessions for employees and members; and

142


-----

- donating 1.5 tons of pre-loved sportswear that would have otherwise gone to landfill, resulting in
a 0.5-ton reduction in CO2 emissions.

As is implicit in our “Everybody Welcome” approach, diversity, inclusion, and belonging (“DIBs”) is
a key part of our DNA and our high-value / low-cost model strives to promote equality and democratize
fitness. We believe that everyone has the right to be, and to feel, safe. Our goal is to create a safe and
positive space for everyone, so they can enjoy the benefits of fitness and wellbeing. Safety is the
cornerstone of a positive experience for our members and employees. Our emergency response and
anti-harassment protocols are best-in-class, and we continue to pioneer initiatives that make a positive
change to gym culture.

In terms of governance and participation in the business, we work to high standards, based around a
well-organized management structure and active employee engagement forums that encourage
equitable participation.

We have made concerted efforts to ensure we have a diverse and representative group of decisionmakers in each of its markets. 45% of our Executive Management Board which directs the business
across the Group are female (including our Group Managing Director) and at a country level, 43% of
the senior management boards in each market are female.

More broadly, our focus on gender balance and initiatives to increase the number of women in senior

Due to disruption in supply caused by the Russia and Ukraine conflict which commenced in February
of 2022, the 2022 energy crisis provided us with a particular opportunity to fast-track our energy
reduction and decarbonization plans. We have been working with a market leading operational
improvement consultant to identify and pursue opportunities to significantly reduce energy usage per
site. A structured implementation program is underway with the objective of delivering improved
energy performance and broader environmental impact across our estate throughout 2023.

We are focused on ways to manage, and reduce where possible, energy consumption in and the
environmental impact of our gyms and have placed emphasis on designing our gyms with a number of
energy saving and “green” features. The following is a selection of features that have been incorporated
throughout the estate, where practically possible:

- mechanical and electrical systems that comply with government energy-saving schemes, including
HMRC’s Enhanced Capital Allowance scheme for energy-saving technologies;

- LED energy-saving lighting and water-saving bathroom and shower facilities;

- energy-efficient fitness equipment, including treadmills, exercise bikes and other self-powered
cardio equipment that have display screens powered by batteries and user-generated electricity;

- control systems for management of heating, ventilation and air-conditioning;

- recycling the building materials from the fit out of our gyms; and

- in some cases, on-site renewable power generation.

Reducing our carbon emissions is the single most important thing that we can do to help slow down
global warming. We have reported on our GHG emissions since 2020 in accordance with our
Streamlined Energy & Carbon Reporting obligations. The forced shutdown of our estate due to COVID19 during 2020, and again in 2021, made it difficult for us to establish a meaningful baseline, a key
dependency for any organization making commitments and setting targets. The incorporation of
Taskforce on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (“TCFDs”) into our annual reporting process for
the year ended December 31, 2023 will include expanded emissions reporting for our global operations

and reporting on additional, categories such as supply chain. Reporting against the TCFDs is an
important step for us providing the necessary framework for climate-related disclosures and supporting
the incorporation of climate-related risk and opportunities into our risk management, strategic planning
and decision-making processes.

We are working towards making a carbon neutral and net zero commitment by the year ended
December 31, 2024. In the meantime, we will continue to deliver our energy efficiency program which
we anticipate will reduce Scope 2 emissions intensity per location by around 20% over the medium
term.

In terms of broader environmental considerations, it should be remembered that the nature of our
business is high volume throughput and high efficiency and therefore inherently sustainable in nature.
Because members effectively “rent” access to the gym facilities and equipment for the hours that they
need the equipment, utilization is high. The alternative is for people to buy their own equipment and
have it at a home, but such equipment would be very lightly utilized, making it a poor use of raw
materials and resources and therefore less sustainable. Gyms are effectively a part of the “sharing
economy” and, especially in the case of low cost/high volume gyms like ours, are a good, sustainable
use of resources.

Another social initiative of ours is the PureGym Trust. We have been able to set up an employee
hardship fund following generous donations from LGP during 2020 in response to the COVID-19
pandemic. The PureGym Trust continues to focus on supporting our employees who are facing
significant financial difficulties.

Furthermore, in order to foster an open and constructive culture, there are multiple routes for staff across

modules. We consistently monitor our health and safety policies and implements changes as needed on
an ongoing basis.

**Government Regulation and Industry Standards**

**_The EUGDPR, the Danish Data Protection Act, the UKGDPR and the UK Data Protection Act_**

EUGDPR came into effect on May 25, 2018 and is supplemented under Danish law by the DDPA,
which replaced the former Danish Act on Processing of Personal Data. UKGDPR, which generally
mirrors the EUGDPR, came into effect on January 31, 2020, as a direct consequence of the UK leaving
the EU, and it is supplemented under UK law by the UKDPA, which replaced the former UK Data
Protection Act 1998. The EUGDPR, DDPA, UKGDPR and UKDPA altogether set out more onerous
and stringent requirements for controllers and processors’ processing of personal data, including
expanded disclosure requirements. For example, when collecting personal data, certain information
must be provided to the individual whose data is being collected. This information includes the identity
of the data controller, the purpose for which the data is being collected and other relevant information
relating to the processing. In some cases, the consent of those data subjects may also be required to
process the personal data for the purposes notified to them. Personal data may only be used for the
purposes notified to individuals. Additionally, regulators now have the ability to impose larger fines of
up to the greater of £17.5 million (€20 million) or up to 4% of the total worldwide annual turnover of
the preceding financial year. In addition to fines, regulators also have the ability to impose other
sanctions such as injunctions and other prohibitive orders.

We have adopted policies and procedures designed to ensure compliance with the EUGDPR, the DDPA,
the UKGDPR, the UKDPA and certain other relevant data protection laws in other jurisdictions in
which we operate. We are registered as a data controller with the Information Commissioner’s Office,
an independent governmental authority responsible for maintaining, upholding and promoting the best
business practices and legislative requirements for processing personal data and safeguarding the
information rights of individuals and their rights to access their personal data. We regularly take legal
advice on EUGDPR, DDPA, UKGDPR and UKDPA-related matters and, where appropriate, involve
our Board of Directors in EUGDPR, DDPA, UKGDPR and UKDPA-related queries. In addition, we
ensure that our staff and suppliers are aware of the EUGDPR, DDPA, UKGDPR and UKDPA’s
requirements. Our policies and procedures are designed to restrict employee access to personal data
(unless required in that employee’s role), ensure that secure methods are used in the collection and

145


-----

transmission of personal data and ensure that we only enter into appropriate data sharing agreements
with our suppliers.

**_Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard_**

The UK PCI DSS is a proprietary information security standard for organizations that handle cardholder
information for the major debit, credit, prepaid, e-purse, ATM, and point-of-sale cards. The PCI DSS
helps to reduce the risk of theft of customers’ card data through controls concerning the storage,
transmission and processing of cardholder data that businesses handle. It also includes standards that
promote the detection of fraud and appropriate reactions to security incidents.

All entities that store, process or transmit cardholder data must be PCI DSS compliant. It is not,
however, mandatory for all entities to obtain formal validation of PCI DSS compliance. Formal
validation requirements depend on the payment brand to which the merchant has subscribed or is in
agreement.

An organization’s compliance with the PCI DSS is validated annually, either by an external Qualified
Security Assessor who creates a Report on Compliance for organizations that handle a large volume of
transactions, or by a Self-Assessment Questionnaire for companies that handle a smaller volume of
transactions.

We make use of a third-party payment services provider and do not store cardholder information on its
own systems; therefore, we complete the self-assessment questionnaire (SAQ A) on an annual basis.

We comply with PCI DSS in Denmark, as we make use of a third-party payment services provider who
stores certain member cardholder information. However, we do also store member payment details for
direct debit collection purposes in our membership database hosted by Exerp.

We also make use of third-party payment service providers in Switzerland and the United States, and
do not store cardholder information on our respective systems in those geographies. Even though we
do not store cardholder information in our respective systems in Switzerland, as our Swiss business is
a Swiss operators it is required to comply with PCI DSS.

**DESCRIPTION OF CERTAIN FINANCING ARRANGEMENTS**

**Intercreditor Agreement**

**_Overview_**

On the Issue Date, the Issuer, Pinnacle Midco 2 Limited (“Holdco”), the agent for the finance parties
under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (the “RCF Facility Agent”), the lenders (the
“RCF Lenders”), arrangers (the “RCF Arrangers”) under the New Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement, the Trustee and the Security Agent, among others, will enter into an intercreditor agreement
(the “Intercreditor Agreement”). Certain hedging providers may accede to the Intercreditor
Agreement in the future. By accepting a Note, the relevant holder thereof shall be deemed to have
agreed to, and accepted the terms and conditions of, the Intercreditor Agreement and shall be deemed
to have authorized the Trustee to enter into to the Intercreditor Agreement on its behalf.

The following description is a summary of certain provisions, among others, contained in the
Intercreditor Agreement and which relate to the rights and obligations of the holders of the Notes. It
does not restate the Intercreditor Agreement in its entirety. As such, you are urged to read the
Intercreditor Agreement because it, and not the description that follows, defines certain rights of the
holders of the Notes.

The Intercreditor Agreement sets out, among other things, the relative ranking of certain indebtedness
of the Debtors, the relative ranking of certain security granted by the Debtors, when payments can be
made in respect of debt of the Debtors, when enforcement action can be taken in respect of that
indebtedness, the terms pursuant to which certain of that indebtedness will be subordinated upon the
occurrence of certain insolvency events and turnover provisions.

Unless otherwise defined in this section or elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum to the extent not
defined in the Intercreditor Agreement, capitalized terms set forth and used in this section have the same
meanings as set forth in the Intercreditor Agreement, which may have different meanings from the
meanings given to such terms and used elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

Lenders and RCF Arrangers, (v) the Original Senior Secured Notes Trustee, (vi) the Security Agent and
(vii) the Original Debtors and Original Intra-Group Lenders.

      - The “Group” means the Issuer and its Restricted Subsidiaries.

**_Ranking and Priority_**

The Intercreditor Agreement provides that the liabilities of the Debtors (other than any Senior Debt
Issuer, as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) shall rank in right and priority of payment in the
following order and are postponed and subordinated to any prior ranking liabilities as follows:

(1) **_first, the liabilities owed to the Super Senior Creditors (the “Super Senior Creditor_**

**Liabilities”), the liabilities owed to the Senior Secured Creditors including with respect to the Notes**
(the “Senior Secured Liabilities”), the liabilities owed to any Hedge Counterparty (the “Hedging
**Liabilities”) (to the extent not already included in the Super Senior Creditor Liabilities), the Permitted**
Senior Secured Financing Liabilities, certain customary costs and expenses of the Trustee and any
Senior Notes Trustee (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) and any representative acting as a
trustee under any issue of notes (the “Trustee Liabilities”), the liabilities owed to any agent (the “Agent
**Liabilities”) under any Debt Documents (as such term is defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) the**
liabilities owed to any arranger under any Debt Document (the “Arranger Liabilities”) and the
liabilities owed to the Security Agent (excluding any parallel debt liabilities or similar), pari passu and
without any preference between them;

(2) **_second, any guarantee liabilities owed to any Permitted Senior Financing Creditor (the_**

“Senior Guarantee Liabilities,” and, together with the Permitted Senior Financing Issuer Liabilities,
the “Senior Liabilities”) pari passu and without any preference between them;

(3) **_third, the Holdco (Proceeds Loans) Liabilities;_**

(4) **_fourth, the Intra-Group Liabilities; and_**

(5) **_fifth, the Holdco Liabilities (other than the Holdco (Proceeds Loans) Liabilities)._**

The Intercreditor Agreement also provides that the liabilities of any Senior Debt Issuer (which term
means Holdco) shall rank in right and priority of payment in the following order and are postponed and
subordinated to any prior ranking liabilities as follows:

(a) **_first, the Super Senior Creditor Liabilities, the Senior Secured Liabilities, the_**

Hedging Liabilities (to the extent not already included in Super Senior Creditor Liabilities), the
Agent Liabilities, the Arranger Liabilities, the liabilities owed to the Security Agent (excluding
any parallel debt liabilities or similar), the Trustee Liabilities, any Senior Liabilities due by any
Senior Debt Issuer in its capacity as a principal debtor with respect to the Permitted Senior
Financing Liabilities (the “Permitted Senior Financing Issuer Liabilities”) pari passu and
without any preference amongst them; and

(b) **_second, any Investor Liabilities._**

**_Priority of Security_**

The Intercreditor Agreement provides that (subject to the proceeds of such security being distributed in
accordance with the Payments Waterfall defined below) the security provided for the Super Senior
Creditor Liabilities, the Senior Secured Liabilities (including the Permitted Senior Secured Financing
Liabilities), the Hedging Liabilities (to the extent not already included in the Super Senior Creditor
Liabilities), the Agent Liabilities, the Arranger Liabilities, the liabilities owed to the Security Agent

Any Senior Debt Issuer may make payments and prepayments in respect of any Senior Liabilities at

**_Restrictions on Enforcement by the Permitted Senior Financing Debt; Senior Standstill Period_**

Without prejudice to the rights of the Permitted Senior Financing Creditors to take Enforcement Action
in relation to the Permitted Senior Financing Issuer Liabilities, prior to the Senior Secured Debt
Discharge Date, no Permitted Senior Financing Creditor shall:

(i) direct the Security Agent to enforce or otherwise require the enforcement of any
Transaction Security; or

(ii) take or require the taking of any Enforcement Action in relation to the Senior Guarantee
Liabilities,

(iii) without the prior consent of or as required by an Instructing Group (as defined below),
except that such restriction will not apply if:

(iv) an event of default under the finance documents in respect of the Senior Liabilities (a
“Senior Event of Default”) is continuing;

157


-----

(v) each Senior Secured Agent has received notice of the relevant Senior Event of Default
from the relevant Permitted Senior Financing Representative;

(vi) a Senior Standstill Period (as defined below) has expired; and

(vii) the relevant Senior Event of Default is continuing at the end of the Senior Standstill
Period.

A “Senior Standstill Period” shall mean the period starting on the date that the relevant

Permitted Senior Financing Representative serves an enforcement notice on each of the Senior Secured
Agents until the earliest of:

(i) 179 days after such date;

(ii) the date on which the Senior Secured Parties take any Enforcement Action in relation
to a particular guarantor of the Senior Liabilities (a “Senior Guarantor”), provided
that the Permitted Senior Financing Creditors may only take the same Enforcement
Action against such Senior Guarantor as is taken by the Senior Secured Parties;

(iii) the date on which an insolvency event occurs in respect of any Senior Guarantor, in
which case Enforcement Action is to be taken only against such Senior Guarantor;

(iv) the date of the consent of the relevant Senior Secured Agents (acting on behalf of the
relevant creditors); and

(v) the expiration of any other Senior Standstill Period which was outstanding at the date
that the current Senior Standstill Period commenced (other than as a result of a cure,
waiver or permitted remedy thereof).

**_Consultation_**

Prior to the Credit Facility Lender Discharge Date, if the Security Agent has received Conflicting
Enforcement Instructions (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement), it shall promptly notify each
Hedge Counterparty (as applicable) and the agents for each of the Super Senior Creditors and/or the
Senior Secured Agents (each, an “Agent”) and each such Agent will consult with each other and the
Security Agent in good faith for 30 days (or as may be agreed) from the earlier of (i) the date of the
latest such Conflicting Enforcement Instruction and (ii) the date falling ten Business Days after the date
the original Enforcement Proposal (as such term is defined in the Intercreditor Agreement) is delivered
in accordance with the Intercreditor Agreement (the “Consultation Period”).

No such consultation shall be required where the Agents are in agreement with regard to any proposed
Enforcement Action, or if:

(i) any of the Transaction Security has become enforceable as a result of an insolvency
event; or

(ii) creditors holding more than 66.67% of the participations in the Super Senior Credit
Liabilities (the “Acceleration Majority Super Senior Creditors”) or the creditors
holding more than 50.1% of the participations in the Senior Secured Liabilities (the
“Acceleration Majority Senior Secured Creditors”) determine in good faith (and
notify each other representative agent of the Super Senior Creditors, the Senior Secured
Creditors and the Permitted Senior Secured Financing Creditors, as applicable) that any
delay caused by such consultation could reasonably be expected to have a material
adverse effect on the Security Agent’s ability to enforce any of the Transaction Security
or the realization proceeds of any enforcement of the Transaction Security.

158


-----

Following the Consultation Period (or if the Consultation Period was terminated or not required as
provided for above), there shall be no further obligation to consult and the Security Agent may act in
accordance with the instructions as to enforcement (an “Enforcement”) then or previously received
from the Instructing Group (as defined below) and the Instructing Group may issue instructions as to
Enforcement to the Security Agent at any time thereafter.

If the Acceleration Majority Super Senior Creditors or the Acceleration Majority Senior Secured
Creditors (acting reasonably) consider that the Security Agent is enforcing the Transaction Security in
a manner which is not consistent with the Security Enforcement Principles (as defined below), subject
to the above, the relevant Senior Secured Agent shall give notice to the other representatives after which
each such representative shall consult with the Security Agent for a period of 30 days (or such lesser
period as the Senior Secured Agents may agree) with a view to agreeing the manner of Enforcement,
_provided that such representatives shall not be obliged to consult more than once in relation to each_
Enforcement.

For the purposes of Enforcement, an “Instructing Group” means,

(i) if prior to the Credit Facility Lender Discharge Date (as that term is defined in the
Intercreditor Agreement), the Acceleration Majority Super Senior Creditors and the
Acceleration Majority Senior Secured Creditors (in each case acting through its
respective Agent), provided that if:

(A) the Super Senior Creditor Liabilities have not been repaid in full in cash within
six months of the date of the first instructions of Enforcement given to the
Security Agent (or withing three months of the first instructions of Enforcement
given to the Security Agent following any failure to pay on the maturity date
of the Credit Facility (as such term is defined in the Intercreditor Agreement));
or

(B) the Security Agent has not commenced any Enforcement (or any transaction in
lieu thereof) or other Enforcement Action within three months of the date of
the first instructions of Enforcement given to the Security Agent,

then the Security Agent shall thereafter follow any instructions that are given (at the same time or
subsequently) by the Acceleration Majority Super Senior Creditors (in each case provided the same
comply with the Security Enforcement Principles (“Qualifying Instructions”) to the exclusion of those
given by the Acceleration Majority Senior Secured Creditors (to the extent conflicting with any
instructions previously given by the Majority Senior Secured Creditors) and “Instructing Group” in
relation to such Enforcement shall mean the Majority Super Senior Creditors.

**_Security Enforcement Principles_**

The Intercreditor Agreement provides that Enforcement instructions must be consistent with the
following principles (the “Security Enforcement Principles”):

(i) It shall be the primary and overriding aim of any enforcement of the Transaction
Security to maximize, so far as is consistent with a prompt and expeditious realization
of value from Enforcement of the Transaction Security, recovery by the Super Senior
Creditors and the Senior Secured Creditors (the “Security Enforcement Objective”).

(ii) The Transaction Security will be enforced and other action as to Enforcement will be
taken such that either (i) all proceeds of Enforcement are received by the Security Agent
in cash for distribution in accordance with the Payments Waterfall (as defined below);
or (ii) if Enforcement is at the direction of the Acceleration Majority Senior Secured
Creditors, sufficient proceeds from Enforcement will be received by the Security Agent
in cash to ensure that when the proceeds are applied in accordance with the Payments
Waterfall, the Super Senior Creditor Liabilities are repaid and discharged in full (unless
the Majority Super Senior Creditors agree otherwise).

(iii) The Enforcement Action must be prompt and expeditious it being acknowledged that,
subject to the other provisions of the Intercreditor Agreement, the time frame for the
realization of value from the Enforcement of the Transaction Security or Distressed
Disposal will be determined by the Instructing Group, provided that it is consistent with
the Security Enforcement Objective.

(iv) On (i) a proposed Enforcement of any of the Transaction Security over assets other than
shares in a member of the Holdco Group, where the aggregate book value of such assets
exceeds £5,000,000 (or its equivalent); or (ii) a proposed Enforcement of any of the
Transaction Security over some or all of the shares in a member of the Holdco Group
over which Transaction Security exists, the Security Agent shall, upon instruction from
the Instructing Group (unless it is incompatible with enforcement proceedings in a
relevant jurisdiction) appoint an accounting firm of international standing and
reputation, any reputable and independent international investment bank or other
reputable and independent professional services firm with experience in restructuring
and enforcement, in each case as selected by the Security Agent acting reasonably and
in good faith (a “Financial Advisor”) to opine as expert that the proceeds received
from any such Enforcement are fair from a financial point of view after taking into
account all relevant circumstances (the “Financial Advisor’s Opinion”).

(v) The Security Agent shall be under no obligation to appoint a Financial Advisor or to
seek the advice of a Financial Advisor, unless expressly required to do so by the
Intercreditor Agreement.

(vi) The Financial Advisor’s Opinion (or any equivalent opinion obtained by the Security
Agent in relation to any other Enforcement of the Transaction Security that such action
is fair from a financial point of view after taking into account all relevant circumstances)
will be conclusive evidence that the Security Enforcement Objective has been met.

(vii) Where the Instructing Group is the Acceleration Majority Senior Secured Creditors, the
Majority Senior Secured Creditors may waive the requirement for a Financial Advisor’s
Opinion where sufficient proceeds from enforcement will be received by the Security
Agent in cash to ensure that when the proceeds are applied in accordance with the

160


-----

Payments Waterfall below, the Super Senior Creditor Liabilities are repaid and
discharged in full.

(viii) In the event that an Enforcement of the Transaction Security is over assets and shares
referred to in (d) above and such Enforcement is conducted by way of public auction,
the Super Senior Creditors and the Senior Secured Creditors shall be entitled to
participate in such auction on the basis of equal information and access rights as other
bidders and financiers in the auction. There is no requirement in the Security
Enforcement Principles summarized in this paragraph (h) that requires the Enforcement
of Transaction Security to take place by way of public auction.

(ix) In the absence of written notice from a Secured Party or group of Secured Parties that
are not part of the relevant Instructing Group that such Secured Party/ies object to any
Enforcement of the Transaction Security on the grounds that such Enforcement Action
does not aim to achieve the Security Enforcement Objective (an “Objection”), the
Security Agent is entitled to assume that such Enforcement of the Transaction Security
is in accordance with the Security Enforcement Objective.

(x) If the Security Agent receives an Objection (and without prejudice to the ability of the
Security Agent to rely on other advisors and/or exercise its own judgment in accordance
with the Intercreditor Agreement), a Financial Advisor’s Opinion (or any equivalent
opinion obtained by the Security Agent in relation to any other Enforcement of the
Transaction Security that such action is fair from a financial point of view after taking
into account all relevant circumstances) to the effect that the particular action could
reasonably be said to be aimed at achieving the Security Enforcement Objective will be
conclusive evidence that the requirement of paragraph (a) above has been met.

The Security Enforcement Principles may be amended, varied or waived with the prior written consent
of the Majority Super Senior Creditors and the Majority Senior Secured Creditors, _provided that no_
additional obligations may be imposed on a member of the Holdco Group without the consent of the
Issuer.

**_Turnover_**

Subject to certain exclusions set out therein, the Intercreditor Agreement also provides that if any Senior
Secured Creditors, Permitted Senior Financing Creditors or Super Senior Creditors (each, a “Primary
**Creditor”) receives or recovers the proceeds of any enforcement of all or part of the Transaction**
Security or any Distressed Disposal other than in accordance with the Payments Waterfall, then it shall:

      - in relation to receipts or recoveries not received or recovered by way of set-off, (i) hold
an amount of that receipt or recovery equal to the relevant liabilities on trust for the
Security Agent and separate from other assets, property or funds and promptly pay that
amount to the Security Agent for application in accordance with the terms of the
Intercreditor Agreement; and (ii) promptly pay an amount equal to the amount (if any)
by which receipt or recovery exceeds the relevant liabilities to the Security Agent for
application in accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement; and

      - in relation to receipts and recoveries received or recovered by way of set-off, promptly
pay an amount equal to that recovery to the Security Agent for application in
accordance with the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement.

Certain further turnover obligations following receipt of non-permitted payments apply to Permitted
Senior Financing Creditors and Subordinated Creditors.

Transaction Security documents;

(b) being effected by enforcement of the Transaction Security in accordance with

the terms of the relevant Transaction Security documents; or

(c) being effected, after the occurrence of an Acceleration Event, by a Debtor or

Holdco to a person or persons which is not a member of the Holdco Group.

Agent is authorized:

**_Option to Purchase_**

Following an acceleration event under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, the Indenture, in
relation to any Permitted Senior Secured Financing Debt or in relation to any Permitted Senior
Financing Debt (including under any Senior Notes Indenture) (an “Acceleration Event”), by giving 10
days’ notice to the Security Agent, the holders of the Notes or the Permitted Senior Secured Financing
Liabilities may require the transfer to them of all, but not part, of the rights, benefits and obligations in
respect of the Credit Facility Lender Liabilities (as each such term is defined in the Intercreditor
Agreement), subject to certain conditions (including but not limited to full payment of all Credit Facility
Lender Liabilities, cash cover, and associated costs and expenses, and provision of certain indemnities).

Following an Acceleration Event or the enforcement of any Transaction Security and after a Senior
Secured Acceleration Event (as defined in the Intercreditor Agreement), a simple majority of the
Permitted Senior Financing Creditors may, by giving 10 days’ notice to the Security Agent, require the
transfer to them of all, but not part, of the rights, benefits and obligations in respect of the Senior Secured
Liabilities, provided that certain conditions are met.

**_Hedging_**

All scheduled payments arising under a Hedging Agreement are permitted payments for the purposes
of the Intercreditor Agreement.

The Intercreditor Agreement contains customary provisions in relation to the circumstances in which a
Priority Hedge Counterparty and a Non-Priority Hedge Counterparty may take Enforcement Action in
relation to its hedging.

**_General_**

**New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement**

**_Overview and structure_**

On or prior to the Issue Date, the Issuer (as original borrower and original guarantor), Barclays Bank
PLC, Deutsche Bank Aktiengesellschaft, Royal Bank of Canada, ING Bank N.V., London Branch and
J.P. Morgan Securities PLC (as lenders), Barclays Bank PLC (as facility agent) and Deutsche Bank AG,
London Branch (as security agent), among others, entered into the New Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement for the provision of a revolving credit facility up to £175,000,000 (the “Original RCF
**Amount”).**

The New Revolving Credit Facility may be utilized by any current or future borrower under the in
pounds sterling, euro, U.S. dollars and Danish kroner or certain other currencies (if agreed) by the
drawing of cash advances, the issue of Letters of Credit (upon the appointment of an Issuing Bank) and
by way of any Ancillary Facilities that may be made available thereunder (each as defined in the New
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). Subject to certain exceptions, loans may be borrowed, repaid
and re-borrowed at any time. Borrowings are available to be used for general corporate and working
capital purposes of the Group (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) including,
without limitation, for payment of interest under the Notes.

In addition, the Issuer may elect to request additional facilities either as a new facility or as additional
tranches of an existing facility under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (the “Additional
**Facility Commitments”)** _provided that the aggregate principle amount of Total Commitments (as_
defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) (including the Additional Facility
Commitments) does not exceed the amount permitted to be incurred under clause (1) of the second
paragraph of the covenant described under “Description of the Notes—Certain Covenants—Limitation
_on Incurrence of Indebtedness and Issuance of Disqualified Stock and Preferred Stock” below. The_
Issuer and the lenders may agree to certain terms in relation to the Additional Facility Commitments,
including the margin, the termination date and the availability period (each subject to parameters as set
out in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement). There are certain limitations on the ability to
incur Additional Facility Commitments.

**_Availability_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility may, subject to the satisfaction of customary conditions precedent,
be utilized from (and including) the Issue Date until the date falling one month prior to the maturity
date of the New Revolving Credit Facility.

**_Borrowers and Guarantors_**

170


-----

The Issuer and Pure Gym Denmark A/S are the original borrowers under the New Revolving Credit
Facility and the Guarantor are the original guarantors under the New Revolving Credit Facility. A
mechanism is included in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement to enable certain of its
subsidiaries to accede as additional borrowers or additional guarantors under the New Revolving Credit
Facility, subject to certain conditions.

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also requires that, subject to, for the avoidance of doubt,
the section entitled “Guarantees” below, in the future each member of the Group (as defined in the New
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) which is required to become a guarantor in order to satisfy the
Guarantor Coverage Test (as defined below), becomes an additional guarantor under the New
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement (subject to agreed security principles).

**_Maturity and Repayment Requirements_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility matures on the date three months prior to the maturity date of the
Notes. Each advance will be repaid on the last day of the interest period relating thereto, subject to a
netting mechanism against amounts to be drawn on such date. All outstanding amounts under the New
Revolving Credit Facility must be repaid in full on or prior to the maturity date for the New Revolving
Credit Facility. Amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans made under the New Revolving Credit
Facility may be re-borrowed during its availability period, subject to certain conditions. The termination
date for a facility under an Additional Facility Commitment is the date agreed between the Issuer and
the relevant lenders.

**_Interest Rate and Fees_**

The interest rate on loans under the New Revolving Credit Facility is the rate per annum equal to the
aggregate of the applicable margin plus SONIA (or in relation to advances in euro, EURIBOR, or in
relation to advances in U.S. dollars, term SOFR, or in relation to advances in Danish kroner, CIBOR)
(as each term is defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) and, in each case, subject to
a zero floor. The initial margin under the New Revolving Credit Facility is 4.00% per annum. If at least
nine months have expired since the Issue Date, provided that no payment (insofar as it relates to nonpayment of principal and/or interest and/or certain fees), financial covenant or insolvency / creditors
process related event of default has occurred and is continuing, the margin on the loans are reduced if
the consolidated senior secured leverage ratio (representing the ratio of Consolidated Senior Secured
Net Indebtedness on such quarter date to Consolidated EBITDA for the period of the most recent four
consecutive financial quarters (subject to certain provisions and adjustments), the first such period
ended on the first quarter date that fell at nine months after the Issue Date (each such term as defined in
the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement)) are met.

A commitment fee is payable on the aggregate undrawn and uncancelled amount of the Original RCF
Amount which accrues from (and including) the Issue Date to (and including) the last day of the
availability period for the New Revolving Credit Facility at the rate of 30% of the then applicable
margin for the New Revolving Credit Facility. The commitment fee is payable quarterly in arrears, on
the last day of the availability period of the New Revolving Credit Facility and on the date the New
Revolving Credit Facility is cancelled in full or on the date on which a lender’s commitment is cancelled.

Default interest on overdue amounts are calculated at a rate which is 1% higher than that applicable to
the loans under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.

The Issuer will pay customary agency fees to the facility agent and the Security Agent in connection
with the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.

**_Guarantees_**

171


-----

The Guarantors (and any of the Issuer’s subsidiaries which accede to the New Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement as additional borrowers or additional guarantors) will provide a senior guarantee of all
amounts payable to the Finance Parties (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement).

Under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement the Issuer will ensured that subject to agreed
security principles, the guarantee provided by the Guarantors under the New Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement represent no less than 80% of the Consolidated EBITDA of the Group (as defined in the
New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) (subject to certain exceptions) (the “Guarantor Coverage
**Test”).**

Furthermore, if on the last day of a fiscal year of the Issuer falling after the Issue Date, the Guarantor
Coverage Test is not satisfied, within 120 days following delivery of the annual financial statements for
the relevant fiscal year, such other restricted subsidiaries of the Issuer (subject to agreed security
principles and certain exceptions) are required to become additional guarantors until the Guarantor
Coverage Test is satisfied (to be calculated as if such additional guarantors had been guarantors on such
last day of the relevant fiscal year).

**_Security_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility benefits from substantially the same security as will be provided
for the Notes. Under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement, proceeds from the enforcement of the
Collateral (whether or not shared with the holders of the Notes) will be required to be applied to repay
indebtedness outstanding in respect of the New Revolving Credit Facility in priority to the Notes.

Any Material Company or other member of the Group (each as defined in the New Revolving Credit
Facility Agreement) which becomes a guarantor of the New Revolving Credit Facility is required
(subject to agreed security principles) to grant certain security interests in favour of the Security Agent.

**_Representations and Warranties_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains certain customary representations and
warranties, subject to certain customary materiality, actual knowledge and other qualifications,
exceptions and baskets, and with certain representations and warranties being repeated, including: (i)
status; (ii) binding obligations; (iii) non-conflict with other obligations; (iv) power and authority; (v)
validity and admissibility in evidence; (vi) governing law and enforcement; and (vii) accuracy of most
recent financial statements delivered.

**_Covenants_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains certain incurrence covenants and related
definitions (with certain adjustments) that may be amended following the Issue Date to reflect the terms
of the Indenture. In addition, the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also contains certain other
affirmative and negative covenants. Set forth below is a brief description of such covenants, all of which
are subject to customary materiality, actual knowledge or other qualifications, exceptions and baskets.

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement also contains a financial covenant, a brief description
of which is set out below.

**_Notes Purchase Condition_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement restricts the repayment, prepayment, purchase,
redemption, defeasance, acquisition or retirement of the principal amount of the Notes or any permitted
refinancing thereof prior to its scheduled maturity date in any manner which involves the payment of
cash consideration by a member of the Group to a person who is not a member of the Group (each as
defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) (a “Notes Payment”). A Notes Payment is
permitted under certain circumstances, including where commitments under the New Revolving Credit

172


-----

Facility are permanently cancelled (and, as applicable, amounts outstanding under the New Revolving
Credit Facility are permanently prepaid) in at least the same proportion as that by which the Notes or
permitted refinancing thereof (as applicable) is repaid, prepaid, purchased, redeemed, defeased,
acquired or otherwise retired (calculated by reference to the total New Revolving Credit Facility
commitments (as of the date the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement is entered into) and the
aggregate principal amount of the Notes or permitted refinancing thereof (as applicable) in existence at
the Issue Date or incurred at any time thereafter). If the commitments under the New Revolving Credit
Facility have been reduced to £30 million no further cancellation and repayment under the Notes
Purchase Condition shall be required as a condition to making a Notes Payment.

**_Affirmative Covenants_**

The affirmative covenants include, among others: (i) providing certain information, including annual
audited and quarterly financial statements, compliance certificates and details of any default (including
the steps, if any, being taken to remedy it); (ii) authorizations, (iii) compliance with laws; (iv) discharge
of taxes; (v) preservation of assets; (vi) maintenance of pari passu ranking of the New Revolving Credit
Facility; (vii) rights of access for the facility agent; (ix) maintenance of intellectual property; (x)
satisfaction of Guarantor Coverage Test; (xi) repayment of certain existing financing arrangements; and
(xii) further assurance provisions.

**_Negative Covenants_**

The negative covenants include restrictions, among others, with respect to: (i) substantially changing
the general nature of the business of the Group (as a whole) (as defined in the New Revolving Credit
Facility Agreement); (ii) the holding company activities of the Issuer; (iii) deliberately changing centres
of main interest; and (iv) non-compliance with economic sanctions. Otherwise, the negative covenants
in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement are substantially the same as the negative covenants
in the Indenture.

**_Mandatory Prepayment Requirements upon a Change of Control_**

On a Change of Control (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement), each lender
under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement shall be entitled for a 30-day period after receiving
notice thereof to require that all amounts payable under the Finance Documents (as defined in the New
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) by the obligors to that lender will become due and payable and
the borrowers will on the date falling 30 days after notice from such lender has been served on the Issuer
and the facility agent prepay or procure the prepayment of all utilizations provided by that lender and
the undrawn commitments of that lender will be cancelled and such lender shall have no obligation to
participate in further utilizations requested under the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement, in each
case save to the extent that any ancillary lender or issuing bank, as between itself and the relevant
member of the Group, agrees to continue to provide an ancillary facility or letter(s) of credit, in which
case, after notification thereof to the facility agent such arrangements shall continue on a bilateral basis
and not as part of, or under, the Finance Documents (each defined term as defined in the New Revolving
Credit Facility Agreement).

**_Financial Covenants_**

If, on any quarter date in respect of the period of the most recent four consecutive financial quarters,
the aggregate amount outstanding of all loan utilizations under the New Revolving Credit Facility
(excluding any amounts utilized by way of Letters of Credit or Ancillary Facilities (as each such term
is defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement)) exceeds an amount equal to 40 per cent.
of the total commitments under the New Revolving Credit Facility, the Issuer is required to confirm
whether or not the Leverage Ratio (as defined in the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement and
representing the ratio of Senior Secured Indebtedness on such quarter date to Consolidated EBITDA
for the period of the most recent four consecutive financial quarters (subject to certain provisions and

173


-----

adjustments) (the first such period being 31 December 2023, each such term as defined in the New
Revolving Credit Facility Agreement)) exceeds 8.80:1.00. The covenant is tested quarterly.

The Issuer is permitted to prevent or cure excesses in the Leverage Ratio as described above by applying
any cure amount (being amounts received by the Issuer in cash pursuant to any new equity or permitted
subordinated debt) as if either (i) Consolidated EBITDA (as defined the New Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement) had been increased by such amount or (ii) Senior Secured Indebtedness (as defined the
New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement) had been reduced by such amount. There is no requirement
to apply any cure amount in prepayment of the New Revolving Credit Facility. No more than five cure
amounts may be taken into account during the term of the New Revolving Credit Facility and no more
than two such cure amounts may be made in any period of four consecutive financial quarters.

**_Events of Default_**

The New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement contains the same events of default, with certain
adjustments, as those applicable to the Notes as set forth in the section entitled “Description of the
_Notes—Events of Default and Remedies”. In addition, the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement_
contains the following events of default:

      - breach of the financial covenant;

      - inaccuracy of a representation or statement when made;

      - breach of the Intercreditor Agreement; and

      - unlawfulness, repudiation and rescission of the finance documents entered into in
connection with the New Revolving Credit Facility Agreement.

**_Disenfranchisement_**

Any holder of the Notes that holds an interest in the New Revolving Credit Facility (other than (i) any
of the original lenders under the New Revolving Credit Facility and (ii) any lender that holds notes debt
on a bona fide trading account and, in the case of both (i) and (ii), that is not acting on behalf of a holder
of the Notes) will be disenfranchised from voting on the New Revolving Credit Facility.

**Subordinated Shareholder Funding**

In connection with the 2017 Acquisition, the Issuer incurred subordinated shareholder indebtedness in
the form of loan notes and an intercompany loan from Pinnacle Midco 2 Limited, each of which are
subordinated under the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and on September 18, 2020, Pinnacle
Midco 2 Limited granted a subordinated shareholder loan to Pinnacle Bidco plc in connection with the
Equity Injection (collectively, the “Subordinated Shareholder Funding”). As of June 30, 2023, the
total amount of subordinated shareholder indebtedness outstanding was £563.7 million (including
accrued and unpaid interest). Until no earlier than the date that is six months subsequent to the maturity
date of the Notes, the Subordinated Shareholder Funding will not require any cash payments, will not
permit enforcements or accelerations and must remain held by holders of the ordinary share capital of
the Issuer. Subordinated Shareholder Funding constitutes “Subordinated Shareholder Funding”
under the Indenture.
